description: Wireshark 2.2.4  is a free and open source network packet sniffer and protocol analyzer developed as a first response tool. It is the most widely-used network protocol analyzer.  I can be used to examine all network traffic because it’s a mini swiss army knife to network administrators who needs detailed visibility into the traffic on their network.  It displays the raw data obtained by the sniffer and turns it into readable and meaningful data so that the user will be able to spot issues as well as correct network problems.  It’s power lies in the ability to help an analyst find the proverbial “needle in a haystack” when the user is up to speed on what to look for and how to do it.  This show helps the network professional get started with Wireshark!

This show helps the network professional get started with Wireshark!

episodes.description: Wireshark 2.2.4 is a free and open source network packet sniffer and protocol analyzer developed as a first response tool. It is the most widely-used network protocol analyzer. I can be used to examine all network traffic because it’s a mini swiss army knife to network administrators who needs detailed visibility into the traffic on their network. It displays the raw data obtained by the sniffer and turns it into readable and meaningful data so that the user will be able to spot issues as well as correct network problems. It’s power lies in the ability to help an analyst find the proverbial “needle in a haystack” when the user is up to speed on what to look for and how to do it. This show helps the network professional get started with Wireshark!
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.074
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03.074 --> 00:00:04.235
Welcome.

3
00:00:04.235 --> 00:00:07.821
If you've ever wondered what Wireshark is,
how to use it, and

4
00:00:07.821 --> 00:00:12.220
perhaps what kind of network protocol
analyzers are available to us, well,

5
00:00:12.220 --> 00:00:14.430
then you're in the right spot.

6
00:00:14.430 --> 00:00:19.020
We really are gonna be taking a look at
how to use this utility to benefit you in

7

your network to analyze the different
types of traffic depending on where

8

you place this within your network, and

what machine do you really wanna focus

10
00:00:29.980 --> 00:00:33.874
So, let's go ahead and hand this off to
Ronnie Wong because he's gonna really

11

explain what we'll be looking
at within these series.

12
00:00:36.654 --> 00:00:41.209
>> All right, as we get started and taking
look at using Wireshark, we, of course,

13
00:00:41.209 --> 00:00:45.236
wanna make sure that you understand
the very basics of how to get set up and

14
00:00:45.236 --> 00:00:47.613
have, not only the knowledge, but also,

15
00:00:47.613 --> 00:00:51.927
of course, a few of the skills that you
need to get started in capturing data.

16
00:00:51.927 --> 00:00:54.700
And, of course,
seeing what you really need.

17
00:00:54.700 --> 00:00:56.570
So, what we're gonna begin with,
of course,

18
00:00:56.570 --> 00:00:59.600
is just a simple installation
of Wireshark as well.

19
00:00:59.600 --> 00:01:02.410
We're gonna talk about what Wireshark is,
but then, of course,

20
00:01:02.410 --> 00:01:03.520
we'll install Wireshark.

21
00:01:03.520 --> 00:01:05.070
I'm gonna show you how to install it,

22
00:01:05.070 --> 00:01:09.330
not only in Windows which is by far
the most popular way to install it.

23
00:01:09.330 --> 00:01:11.329
We'll also do it on the MacBook 2 and

24
00:01:11.329 --> 00:01:15.400
then, we'll also show you how you can

25
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:20.759
From that point, we would jump in to
just showing you how to do a basic

26
00:01:20.759 --> 00:01:27.530
type of packet capturing, which is just
getting all the data onto your machine.

27
00:01:27.530 --> 00:01:32.790
From that point, you can use it to analyze
the amount of data that you have captured.

28
00:01:32.790 --> 00:01:36.910
So we're gonna perform a simple type
of data capture available for us.

29
00:01:36.910 --> 00:01:40.090
Then, of course, now that you know
how to do those basic things,

30
00:01:40.090 --> 00:01:43.670
it's the interface that can be really
confusing at times because there are so

31
00:01:43.670 --> 00:01:45.060
many different options.

32
00:01:45.060 --> 00:01:48.960
We're gonna walk you through
the most basic of the interface so

33
00:01:48.960 --> 00:01:52.340
that you understand what you're seeing and
what the layout is, and of course,

34
00:01:52.340 --> 00:01:54.830
how you can get access
to some of the tools.

35
00:01:54.830 --> 00:01:58.220
And the beginning area is making sure,
of course, that we can start and

36
00:01:58.220 --> 00:02:00.500
stop the capture as we need to.

37
00:02:01.540 --> 00:02:05.690
Of course, with all the data
on our machines at this point,

38
00:02:05.690 --> 00:02:10.750
the problem that we have is simple,
is now we have a gigantic virtual haystack

39
00:02:10.750 --> 00:02:14.200
of all of these different
sleevers of data that we have.

40
00:02:14.200 --> 00:02:16.400
How is it that we begin to pinpoint or

41
00:02:16.400 --> 00:02:19.280
find that one needle in
a haystack that we need?

42
00:02:19.280 --> 00:02:23.860
We'll talk a bit about using different
filters that will help us to begin to

43
00:02:23.860 --> 00:02:27.970
whittle down that haystack to
really isolate and focus down

44
00:02:27.970 --> 00:02:33.350
on the packets that we're really trying
to take a look at as well, okay?

45
00:02:33.350 --> 00:02:36.460
Now, even though you think we
should be done at that point, well,

46
00:02:36.460 --> 00:02:40.130
there are advanced features that we can
also talk about too, which of course,

47
00:02:40.130 --> 00:02:47.400
is being able to capture the conversation
of the data between two machines, right?

48
00:02:47.400 --> 00:02:49.840
So not only seeing one side of a capture,
but

49
00:02:49.840 --> 00:02:54.660
actually being able to see if the data can
flow on both sides of the capture as well.

50
00:02:54.660 --> 00:02:58.660
We'll take a look at doing that, as well
as, of course, using some of the expert

51
00:02:58.660 --> 00:03:03.330
information tools that we'll see, that are
also built into Wireshark to help us to

52
00:03:03.330 --> 00:03:07.040
kind of pinpoint in the unusual
traffic that we're analyzing.

53
00:03:07.040 --> 00:03:11.039
Especially for errors and for warnings
that are going on in our systems or for

54
00:03:11.039 --> 00:03:14.554
problems, we'll also be able to
use that to help us to focus them.

55
00:03:14.554 --> 00:03:18.618
And then, of course,
lastly we'll start setting it up here for

56
00:03:18.618 --> 00:03:23.320
taking a look at the statistical
information that we can also find out.

57
00:03:23.320 --> 00:03:26.550
We'll take a look at the most
general types of statistics and

58
00:03:26.550 --> 00:03:29.770
then we'll move into the realm
of protocols specific types of

59
00:03:30.950 --> 00:03:33.730
statistics that we can
also take advantage of.

60
00:03:33.730 --> 00:03:38.100
But, if you say, hey, I haven't
really worked with Wireshark before,

61
00:03:38.100 --> 00:03:40.510
this is a great place for you to begin.

62
00:03:40.510 --> 00:03:44.360
If you need a refresher,
this is a great place for you to begin.

63
00:03:44.360 --> 00:03:49.420
As this series is really about
the foundation of learning about it,

64
00:03:49.420 --> 00:03:53.220
we think that this will really help you,
especially if you're getting started in

65
00:03:53.220 --> 00:03:56.580
it, to begin to use it, and
to feel more comfortable with it.

66
00:03:56.580 --> 00:03:58.960
This series has the potential,
of course, of going on and

67
00:03:58.960 --> 00:04:03.920
actually developing later content
which will add on to the end of this

68
00:04:03.920 --> 00:04:09.880
particular short series of shows to
probably do more scenario types of

69
00:04:09.880 --> 00:04:13.550
examination of data as it goes
across our interfaces too.

70
00:04:13.550 --> 00:04:17.770
So, check back every once in a while as
you're watching through these series, and

71
00:04:17.770 --> 00:04:19.320
you might see one, two,

72
00:04:19.320 --> 00:04:22.620
or maybe even three or four different
episodes start adding in and

73
00:04:22.620 --> 00:04:27.000
filling out Wireshark to help us to make
it the best possible show that we can.

74
00:04:27.000 --> 00:04:30.096
But at least this will get you
a great start and a beginning.

75
00:04:30.096 --> 00:04:34.046
So, if you are ready to actually start
taking that journey, get ready for

76
00:04:34.046 --> 00:04:37.501
that very first episode, and
Cherokee and I will see you there.

77
00:04:37.501 --> 00:04:41.194
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee introduce the protocol analyzing tool  Wireshark. Ronnie explains the differences between the terms packet capture, packet analyzer and protocol analyzer. You will also lean a brief history and description in addition to system requirements.
episodes.title: What is Wireshark
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.220
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.220 --> 00:00:02.460
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.460 --> 00:00:06.260
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.260 --> 00:00:08.156
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.156 --> 00:00:11.877
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.877 --> 00:00:14.460
>> Welcome to your Wireshark show.

7
00:00:14.460 --> 00:00:16.740
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:16.740 --> 00:00:22.470
In this episode we will be introducing
you to version 2.2.4 with Wireshark.

9
00:00:22.470 --> 00:00:26.290
Today in studios we have Ronnie Wong
to help us cover this topic.

10
00:00:26.290 --> 00:00:28.820
Now, thank you for
joining us today, Ronnie.

11
00:00:28.820 --> 00:00:31.200
Now, we see this topic,
it says what is Wireshark?

12
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:34.272
I almost feel like I should be saying
it in a Jeopardy question format.

13
00:00:34.272 --> 00:00:36.220
Are we gonna be playing
some kind of game today?

14
00:00:36.220 --> 00:00:39.530
>> Well, to a point,
it's sort of like a game, right?

15
00:00:39.530 --> 00:00:44.640
Wireshark is a great utility that
everybody in networking should get at

16
00:00:44.640 --> 00:00:49.960
least the most basic familiarity with
because you can learn a lot by discovering

17
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:53.580
more about your network traffic
than you really think that you can.

18
00:00:53.580 --> 00:00:58.909
So when we first start off, with the idea
here of networking, most of us do end up,

19
00:00:58.909 --> 00:01:04.658
and we've taken any type of instructor-led
class we've learned about the OSI model.

20
00:01:04.658 --> 00:01:09.705
We understand how certain devices end up
working together, and all that is some

21
00:01:09.705 --> 00:01:15.080
prerequisite knowledge that you will
have to have as you work with Wireshark.

22
00:01:15.080 --> 00:01:19.540
But overall though, even though we
might understand the theory behind it,

23
00:01:19.540 --> 00:01:22.690
most of us don't get to see it
actually apply in action nor

24
00:01:22.690 --> 00:01:26.780
get to see the interactions that
end up on our networks as well.

25
00:01:26.780 --> 00:01:31.610
Wireshark essentially helps to
reveal a lot of that information,

26
00:01:31.610 --> 00:01:36.620
not through the theory and knowledge
of just connecting devices together.

27
00:01:36.620 --> 00:01:41.230
But we can actually take the traffic that
goes on between two communicating devices

28
00:01:41.230 --> 00:01:45.890
and applications and be able to see
the interactions that happen with them.

29
00:01:45.890 --> 00:01:51.030
So it is a great utility and tool for
anybody in networking to make

30
00:01:51.030 --> 00:01:56.210
sure that you at least have some grasp of
this tool and the scope and the nature.

31
00:01:56.210 --> 00:01:59.360
So that way if somebody says,
I need to find this out.

32
00:01:59.360 --> 00:02:01.500
Is there a possible way we can do that?

33
00:02:01.500 --> 00:02:05.550
Well, more than likely for you to
find out some experiences like that,

34
00:02:05.550 --> 00:02:09.570
such as why a server may be acting
slowly across the network, or

35
00:02:09.570 --> 00:02:12.080
why connections are being dropped,
Wireshark can

36
00:02:12.080 --> 00:02:15.570
help you to be able to troubleshoot
things like that if you need to.

37
00:02:15.570 --> 00:02:20.239
So that is why we're actually taking
a little bit of time to focus in on

38
00:02:20.239 --> 00:02:22.505
the notion of Wireshark itself.

39
00:02:22.505 --> 00:02:27.239
But when it comes down to what is
Wireshark, it's really kind of

40
00:02:27.239 --> 00:02:32.690
a mini Swiss Army knife of
networking utilities that we have.

41
00:02:32.690 --> 00:02:36.466
Now by that, I really do mean that it has
a couple of utilities that are kind of

42
00:02:36.466 --> 00:02:37.826
combined together as one.

43
00:02:37.826 --> 00:02:40.093
>> It can get a little
confusing sometimes,

44
00:02:40.093 --> 00:02:43.130
if you hear the term packet capture or
sniffer.

45
00:02:43.130 --> 00:02:45.700
Ronnie, is there some way that you can
kind of just break that down for us, and

46
00:02:45.700 --> 00:02:47.040
explain the difference here?

47
00:02:47.040 --> 00:02:50.230
Or between the different tools,
we hear packet analyzer.

48
00:02:50.230 --> 00:02:53.870
>> Yeah, it actually is a little bit
confusing when you're first beginning and

49
00:02:53.870 --> 00:02:56.430
you hear those terms like
just put a packet sniffer, or

50
00:02:56.430 --> 00:02:58.400
sniff the traffic a little bit.

51
00:02:58.400 --> 00:03:00.870
You have different imagery
if you're like me and

52
00:03:00.870 --> 00:03:02.670
you came from a different background.

53
00:03:02.670 --> 00:03:04.353
Does network traffic smell in some way?

54
00:03:04.353 --> 00:03:05.872
Well, to a point.

55
00:03:05.872 --> 00:03:08.926
>> For me, I always think of like we
were talking about even before the show,

56
00:03:08.926 --> 00:03:10.320
is it hardware, is it software?

57
00:03:10.320 --> 00:03:11.846
Which angle are you going here?

58
00:03:11.846 --> 00:03:15.761
>> Well, actually it's both when it
comes down to the very realization.

59
00:03:15.761 --> 00:03:18.358
When we start talking about
the idea of what Wireshark is,

60
00:03:18.358 --> 00:03:19.962
it's a couple of those utilities.

61
00:03:19.962 --> 00:03:22.061
Like I said,
think about a mini Swiss Army knife.

62
00:03:22.061 --> 00:03:24.484
Now, it's not the complete, thick,

63
00:03:24.484 --> 00:03:28.092
gigantic 64-tool Swiss Army
knife of all networking.

64
00:03:28.092 --> 00:03:31.912
But it at least contains some of the most
valuable tools that we normally need to do

65
00:03:31.912 --> 00:03:34.732
so that we can see the traffic
as it goes across the network.

66
00:03:34.732 --> 00:03:39.025
And so that begins what what we
call some type of packet sniffer,

67
00:03:39.025 --> 00:03:42.214
as well as what we call a packet analyzer,
too.

68
00:03:42.214 --> 00:03:44.386
Now when we combine
both of those together,

69
00:03:44.386 --> 00:03:47.930
we end up getting what we call
a protocol analyzer altogether.

70
00:03:47.930 --> 00:03:50.680
So let's break down
the individual components just for

71
00:03:50.680 --> 00:03:53.810
a moment to make sure that
we understand this, right?

72
00:03:53.810 --> 00:03:56.490
When it comes down to what
we call a packet sniffer or

73
00:03:56.490 --> 00:04:01.440
a packet capture utility of some sort,
what we're actually saying here is that

74
00:04:01.440 --> 00:04:06.020
it really helps us to be able
to see the data on the network.

75
00:04:06.020 --> 00:04:09.950
Now, the problem that we have in reality,
right?

76
00:04:09.950 --> 00:04:14.570
If you were to pull out my
wire right here to my network

77
00:04:14.570 --> 00:04:19.200
adapter on my machine right now,
you can't see anything, right?

78
00:04:19.200 --> 00:04:21.020
It doesn't show you anything.

79
00:04:21.020 --> 00:04:25.050
The only thing that you could possibly
do right now in the earliest days of

80
00:04:25.050 --> 00:04:28.810
networking is that you could
hook it up to an oscilloscope.

81
00:04:28.810 --> 00:04:30.720
And then you'd see some sine wave.

82
00:04:30.720 --> 00:04:34.280
You'd see a little bit of blips and
stuff like that going across.

83
00:04:34.280 --> 00:04:36.835
To you and me,
that's not very readable, okay?

84
00:04:36.835 --> 00:04:40.980
It really doesn't give us anything,
except it's fascinating to watch.

85
00:04:40.980 --> 00:04:44.040
And then when somebody explains to you a
little bit about what these actually mean,

86
00:04:44.040 --> 00:04:47.900
then you're kind of a little bit more
fascinated by the very fact of it.

87
00:04:47.900 --> 00:04:51.610
But that all begins with
some utility that we have

88
00:04:51.610 --> 00:04:55.380
that can help us to see those blips and
those sine waves and

89
00:04:55.380 --> 00:04:58.150
some of those different
things that we have in place.

90
00:04:58.150 --> 00:05:02.073
Packet-capturing utilities,
whether they're hardware-based or

91
00:05:02.073 --> 00:05:05.180
software-based, essentially do that for
us.

92
00:05:05.180 --> 00:05:09.633
An oscilloscope is essentially
a packet-capturing type of utility to

93
00:05:09.633 --> 00:05:10.752
a point, right?

94
00:05:10.752 --> 00:05:13.940
It allows us to see
the information going across.

95
00:05:13.940 --> 00:05:16.930
And if that oscilloscope is hooked
up to some type of printer,

96
00:05:16.930 --> 00:05:20.560
we can now go ahead and
see those blips going across, as well.

97
00:05:20.560 --> 00:05:22.701
And then be able to analyze that later on.

98
00:05:22.701 --> 00:05:26.377
>> Maybe make some correlations about
different types of communications, but

99
00:05:26.377 --> 00:05:27.930
it's not really detailed.

100
00:05:27.930 --> 00:05:29.630
>> Yeah, for an engineer,

101
00:05:29.630 --> 00:05:32.560
it might be enough that he could go,
here's where you're experiencing issues,

102
00:05:32.560 --> 00:05:34.252
but for Ronnie Wong, there's just-

103
00:05:34.252 --> 00:05:34.785
>> [LAUGH]
>> No way.

104
00:05:34.785 --> 00:05:37.150
I'd just go all right,
that means nothing to me.

105
00:05:37.150 --> 00:05:38.820
There's nothing that we have.

106
00:05:38.820 --> 00:05:40.370
But it has to begin somewhere.

107
00:05:40.370 --> 00:05:43.620
And the somewhere that we
begin is by capturing or

108
00:05:43.620 --> 00:05:48.096
by making sure that we can see
the data going across something.

109
00:05:48.096 --> 00:05:52.160
Packet-capture utilities, especially in
networking data, what they do is that they

110
00:05:52.160 --> 00:05:56.630
pretty much watch the NIC, the network
interface card, on your network.

111
00:05:56.630 --> 00:06:01.340
And whatever traffic flows across
that interface it says, hey,

112
00:06:01.340 --> 00:06:03.770
let me go ahead and
make a capture of that.

113
00:06:03.770 --> 00:06:06.700
In other words, capture those
packets that are going across.

114
00:06:06.700 --> 00:06:08.390
And let me print them out somewhere.

115
00:06:08.390 --> 00:06:10.390
Now, when we talk about
printing them out somewhere or

116
00:06:10.390 --> 00:06:12.880
saving them somewhere where do we mean?

117
00:06:12.880 --> 00:06:16.170
Normally at this point we're
probably just talking about RAM, but

118
00:06:16.170 --> 00:06:20.420
these utilities can have it where you
go ahead and just print it to a file.

119
00:06:20.420 --> 00:06:22.250
Which means to save it into a file and

120
00:06:22.250 --> 00:06:25.240
then you can examine the data
a little bit later on.

121
00:06:25.240 --> 00:06:28.190
Sometimes it might print
it directly to the screen.

122
00:06:28.190 --> 00:06:31.790
When you take a look at it, well then
you can actually see the information.

123
00:06:31.790 --> 00:06:35.280
And some of them do it live-time for
you, where, as soon as it captures,

124
00:06:35.280 --> 00:06:37.300
it sends it to the screen.

125
00:06:37.300 --> 00:06:41.470
Now, it also depends on a couple of other
configurations that have to happen.

126
00:06:41.470 --> 00:06:45.400
But overall though,
that's what a packet-capture utility does.

127
00:06:45.400 --> 00:06:50.610
It monitors the NIC for all of the actual

Well for Wireshark, they went ahead and
there's not only support for Windows.

350
00:19:47.610 --> 00:19:50.621
Another words in you can run it on
Windows, but you can also run it on Linux.

351
00:19:50.621 --> 00:19:56.374
Those two additions were really built
up from kinda the very beginning,

352
00:19:56.374 --> 00:20:00.900
and then because Mac became
more popular they even ported

353
00:20:00.900 --> 00:20:05.634
something from Linux over to Mac
because it was a BS max BSD.

354
00:20:05.634 --> 00:20:09.316
You might still see some of those
remnants around on earlier versions, but

355
00:20:09.316 --> 00:20:13.115
now today at least in the latest version
you probably don't even have to worry

356
00:20:13.115 --> 00:20:14.180
about it.

357
00:20:14.180 --> 00:20:17.030
And we'll talk about that
during the installation, but

358
00:20:17.030 --> 00:20:21.210
just kind of realize that there
are different options available.

359
00:20:21.210 --> 00:20:24.840
Whether you're running a Mac or
whether you're running a Linux machine,

360
00:20:24.840 --> 00:20:28.930
whether you're running Windows, Wireshark
will actually help us do that, too.

361
00:20:28.930 --> 00:20:32.800
>> All right, so if this piece of
software is platform independent or

362
00:20:32.800 --> 00:20:35.900
well, considering the ones that you just
spoke of, are there any other system

363
00:20:35.900 --> 00:20:39.280
requirements or things that I should
be aware of before I try to install?

364
00:20:39.280 --> 00:20:41.290
>> Well, there are a couple of them.

365
00:20:41.290 --> 00:20:45.090
Overall though, the great thing is it
doesn't actually have any gigantic

366
00:20:45.090 --> 00:20:48.120
system requirements for
the machines to run.

367
00:20:49.290 --> 00:20:52.560
It's a relatively small piece of software,
and

368
00:20:52.560 --> 00:20:57.670
it doesn't need a gigantic CPU or
a ton of RAM.

369
00:20:57.670 --> 00:20:59.450
But it does need some.

370
00:20:59.450 --> 00:21:02.920
But there's no real hardware
requirements for making it run and

371
00:21:02.920 --> 00:21:07.570
in today's networks it probably
doesn't really require much at all.

372
00:21:07.570 --> 00:21:11.050
It used to be where a software like
this might have actually said,

373
00:21:11.050 --> 00:21:16.650
you need to 256 megs of RAM,
and 15 megabytes of free space.

374
00:21:16.650 --> 00:21:18.940
Most machines handle that fairly well.

375
00:21:18.940 --> 00:21:22.160
But Wireshark the real requirement here

376
00:21:22.160 --> 00:21:25.160
comes down to of course
the physical NIC itself.

377
00:21:25.160 --> 00:21:30.280
The great thing is most of the NIC on
computers today will allow you to operate

378
00:21:30.280 --> 00:21:35.160
in a mode that will be beneficial if
you're going to be using Wireshark,

379
00:21:35.160 --> 00:21:38.527
which is what we call
promiscuous mode is the key.

380
00:21:38.527 --> 00:21:41.151
The NIC has to support what
are called promiscuous mode.

381
00:21:41.151 --> 00:21:41.838
>> Okay.

382
00:21:41.838 --> 00:21:44.940
>> Now if you don't know what that means,
that's kinda the problem here.

383
00:21:46.660 --> 00:21:49.860
Let's kind of imagine a little bit of
network traffic here as it comes into

384
00:21:49.860 --> 00:21:51.200
my machine.

385
00:21:51.200 --> 00:21:55.430
Well if my machine gets
information that's destined for

386
00:21:55.430 --> 00:21:59.170
Cherokee's machine by accident, it
shouldn't happen, but let's say it does.

387
00:21:59.170 --> 00:22:01.260
Let's say it's something like that.

388
00:22:01.260 --> 00:22:04.870
Well, essentially my NIC just goes,
I'm not even gonna worry about it.

389
00:22:04.870 --> 00:22:08.290
I'm just gonna drop that traffic,
cuz it's not destined for me.

390
00:22:08.290 --> 00:22:12.270
Well that means that the NIC itself
just says, I'm not looking for it.

391
00:22:12.270 --> 00:22:13.670
>> You lost it.
>> I don't care about it, yeah,

392
00:22:13.670 --> 00:22:15.880
we'll just drop it, no big deal.

393
00:22:15.880 --> 00:22:20.870
Promiscuous mode allows us instead to say
let's just go ahead and make a, if we want

394
00:22:20.870 --> 00:22:26.670
to we can even see that data and be able
to make a capture of it if we choose to.

395
00:22:26.670 --> 00:22:28.950
To go ahead and do so.

396
00:22:28.950 --> 00:22:34.390
I can then put my machine in a situation
where if I'm running Wireshark on

397
00:22:34.390 --> 00:22:41.140
my machine, I can capture more data than
that has just destined for my own machine.

398
00:22:41.140 --> 00:22:43.980
But your NICs have to
support in promiscuous mode.

399
00:22:43.980 --> 00:22:45.920
>> And that's kind of something
like we were talking about.

400
00:22:45.920 --> 00:22:50.230
We, before this show Ronnie, when we were
looking at those alpha cards on Amazon and

401
00:22:50.230 --> 00:22:55.380
if you think about it how many
companies or individuals use wireless?

402
00:22:55.380 --> 00:22:57.560
And we have like all these signals
floating around our heads and

403
00:22:57.560 --> 00:22:58.900
it's crazy popular now.

404
00:23:00.310 --> 00:23:04.150
The chances of being able to
capture some of those management

405
00:23:04.150 --> 00:23:07.880
frames that are sent in plain text and
then we can go ahead and craft.

406
00:23:07.880 --> 00:23:09.886
And that's where you hear
terms like injection and

407
00:23:09.886 --> 00:23:11.500
manipulation and things like that,

408
00:23:11.500 --> 00:23:15.250
but that's essentially what we're doing
here when we run in that promiscuous mode.

409
00:23:15.250 --> 00:23:16.130
>> It really is.

410
00:23:16.130 --> 00:23:19.446
And that's actually another neat feature
since you mentioned the idea of wireless.

411
00:23:19.446 --> 00:23:24.879
Is that early types of devices like this,
these they might have allow

412
00:23:24.879 --> 00:23:30.748
you to only capture based on the physical
NIC itself in terms of a wired connection.

413
00:23:30.748 --> 00:23:33.554
But Wireshark doesn't care one way or

414
00:23:33.554 --> 00:23:39.349
another as long as you're wireless NIC
has the ability also to send that data.

415
00:23:39.349 --> 00:23:43.240
We've also ended up looking at not only
the alpha cards a little bit before

416
00:23:43.240 --> 00:23:47.507
the show but Wireshark's parent kind of
sponsor, they produced their own, and

417
00:23:47.507 --> 00:23:50.352
we were looking at it,
it was pretty expensive here.

418
00:23:50.352 --> 00:23:54.138
But they have a called an Air P Cap Card,
and it's exactly like it sounds.

419
00:23:54.138 --> 00:23:56.378
I mean, it's wireless or air.

420
00:23:56.378 --> 00:23:58.109
Pcap means packet capture,

421
00:23:58.109 --> 00:24:02.227
a network adapter that they can allow
you to plug in through the USB.

422
00:24:02.227 --> 00:24:03.830
And that was several hundred dollars.

423
00:24:03.830 --> 00:24:04.970
>> Almost 700.

424
00:24:04.970 --> 00:24:07.090
>> More than likely,
it's probably worth it, okay?

425
00:24:07.090 --> 00:24:11.920
When it comes down to what we normally
need to do on the network, it's either, we

426
00:24:11.920 --> 00:24:15.910
try and just work off of our own wireless,
and hope that we capture everything.

427
00:24:15.910 --> 00:24:19.980
Or we actually have this special dedicated
device that's designed to do it which,

428
00:24:19.980 --> 00:24:23.160
if you're in this realm of
being a network analyst,

429
00:24:23.160 --> 00:24:25.320
it may be worth every single dime.

430
00:24:25.320 --> 00:24:28.840
I'm not gonna say it's not worth it at
all, but whether you're talking about

431
00:24:28.840 --> 00:24:32.350
the alpha one or whether you're talking
about something like this, it's probably

432
00:24:32.350 --> 00:24:36.090
worth every single penny if this is what
you're gonna be doing full time, okay?

433
00:24:36.090 --> 00:24:40.780
So it really has to do with that idea that
promiscuous mode more than anything else.

434
00:24:40.780 --> 00:24:43.670
As you start capturing data,
if you capture it live, right?

435
00:24:43.670 --> 00:24:49.550
The only real requirement is to understand
that if you just leave it on 24

436
00:24:49.550 --> 00:24:55.270
hours a day, there is gonna come a point
where you may run out of hard drive space.

437
00:24:55.270 --> 00:24:56.740
In theory it shouldn't happen,

438
00:24:56.740 --> 00:25:00.250
especially with as big as a hard
drives are today, but you never know.

439
00:25:00.250 --> 00:25:04.880
Because it is, it's making a copy of every
single thing that's hitting your nick, and

440
00:25:04.880 --> 00:25:09.520
sending it into a file,
which is gonna fill up on your hard drive.

441
00:25:09.520 --> 00:25:11.460
Or if you're trying to send
it just in Wireshark and

442
00:25:11.460 --> 00:25:12.930
you've got it running in the background,

443
00:25:12.930 --> 00:25:16.210
it's gonna send it to your display which
means it's gotta keep it all in RAM.

444
00:25:16.210 --> 00:25:20.080
More than likely, you're gonna run
out of RAM at some point in time.

445
00:25:20.080 --> 00:25:22.480
Either way it's gonna end
up stopping the capture.

446
00:25:22.480 --> 00:25:26.310
Overall, though, you just have to
think about some of these things.

447
00:25:26.310 --> 00:25:31.243
But the great thing is, if you are really
interested then, in at least getting

448
00:25:31.243 --> 00:25:35.452
the nature of beginning through
understand how to use Wireshark.

449
00:25:35.452 --> 00:25:39.711
You're in a great place, cuz that's what
we're gonna do is we're gonna show you

450
00:25:39.711 --> 00:25:43.044
kind of the very basics of getting
started and using Wireshark,

451
00:25:43.044 --> 00:25:47.980
as well as the utilities that, they're
really, filters are kind of the key thing.

452
00:25:47.980 --> 00:25:51.490
But then we're gonna actually get into
a little bit of deeper things as well,

453
00:25:51.490 --> 00:25:55.730
talk about where they're actually used,
maybe in some case scenarios instead.

454
00:25:55.730 --> 00:25:58.020
And see where that leads us in the future.

455
00:25:58.020 --> 00:26:01.690
So the great thing is, this is where
we're gonna start off as right here, and

456
00:26:01.690 --> 00:26:03.920
we're gonna take a look at installing.

457
00:26:03.920 --> 00:26:07.900
But at this point I think I've actually
ran out of time by continuing the talk so

458
00:26:07.900 --> 00:26:10.460
this is a good point for
us to kind of stop.

459
00:26:10.460 --> 00:26:13.095
>> That's okay, I mean we were
talking about a lot of exciting stuff,

460
00:26:13.095 --> 00:26:16.166
Wireshark is the coolest utility and
that's a great introduction, Ronnie.

461
00:26:16.166 --> 00:26:19.915
So thank you so much for that, but we do
have a lot more information to cover.

462
00:26:19.915 --> 00:26:22.398
I can't wait to see where to get it,
how to install it, and

463
00:26:22.398 --> 00:26:23.476
how to use this utility.

464
00:26:23.476 --> 00:26:27.183
So thank you so much for joining us today,
and thank you ladies and gentlemen for

465
00:26:27.183 --> 00:26:30.690
joining as well, but stay tuned,
we have more Wireshark headed your way.

466
00:26:30.690 --> 00:26:32.700
For this show we'll go ahead and sign off.

467
00:26:32.700 --> 00:26:34.280
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

468
00:26:34.280 --> 00:26:35.070
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

469
00:26:35.070 --> 00:26:37.910
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

470
00:26:37.910 --> 00:26:43.783
[MUSIC]

471
00:26:43.783 --> 00:26:47.143
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show Ronnie and Cherokee explain how to install Wireshark on different platforms. First, Ronnie walks through a Windows install followed by Mac OS X and Linux installations.
episodes.title: Install Wireshark

There's a couple of things that

There's some times where it's just,

That's when we have to worry

So we'll talk about at least that

>> All right, you mentioned a couple

>> Of course natively, it was designed for

49
00:02:20.120 --> 00:02:24.020
that we wanna make sure that when we start
installing that we know how to do this.

50
00:02:24.020 --> 00:02:27.210
Most of us understand
how to install software.

51
00:02:27.210 --> 00:02:29.370
So I know this seems

Just bear with use and make sure that

Now as far as obtaining Wireshark.

You can get it in many different places,
okay?

So let me give you a for instance.

I use a network simulator or

That is called GNS3.

This is a router simulator, so

But even in GNS3 today,

So that way,

So there are times where you don't

So don't mistake that.

Don't think that every single time

You can.

That's what we're going to be

But you may end up finding out that it

78
00:03:49.980 --> 00:03:50.720
running as well.

79
00:03:52.320 --> 00:03:58.064
Case, also has another system that they

00:03:58.064 --> 00:04:03.197
So you name it, there's several pieces

00:04:03.197 --> 00:04:08.342
Wireshark directly into everything that

00:04:08.342 --> 00:04:12.378
So that way they don't have to worry about

again, click on it, and then figure

So you can get it for free that way.

00:04:18.144 --> 00:04:21.872
There are sometimes where

And it really is just kind

So somebody could make you pay for it.

Not necessarily, it shouldn't be, but

00:04:37.930 --> 00:04:40.490
it as well if they put

00:04:40.490 --> 00:04:44.350
So just kind of realize that because
open source people can develop it and

00:04:44.350 --> 00:04:46.300

94
00:04:46.300 --> 00:04:50.510
So you can get it in many different ways,
but the easiest way if you're not sure and

95
00:04:50.510 --> 00:04:53.300
you're just trying to learn

installing it direct, or downloading it,
excuse me, from their website.

The key here is to understand that
when you start to capture data,

33
00:01:45.523 --> 00:01:50.510
it can appear differently depending
on where you capture the data.

34
00:01:50.510 --> 00:01:53.960
And how you also capture data is also key,
right?

35
00:01:53.960 --> 00:01:58.490
So once it's installed and
you decide to do this, placement is key.

36
00:01:58.490 --> 00:02:00.980
What you want to do is,

37
00:02:00.980 --> 00:02:04.970
when you start to actually understand
that you may need to run Wireshark.

38
00:02:04.970 --> 00:02:08.380
Usually it comes from a user indicating

39
00:02:08.380 --> 00:02:12.160
that something is not
the way that it should be.

40
00:02:12.160 --> 00:02:15.871
The network is slow, or
I'm not able to receive this,

41
00:02:15.871 --> 00:02:20.405
or I'm only getting something partially,
whatever it might be.

42
00:02:20.405 --> 00:02:24.758
You always want to try and
run Wireshark as close as you

43
00:02:24.758 --> 00:02:29.610
can to whoever is actually
giving that particular report.

44
00:02:31.230 --> 00:02:34.490
So let's say for
instance here that the end user sitting on

45
00:02:34.490 --> 00:02:38.430
this particular network,
they are saying that from their desktop

46
00:02:38.430 --> 00:02:42.750
they're not getting access to
files the way that they need to.

47
00:02:42.750 --> 00:02:48.590
Well, you can run Wireshark from this
particular location or very close.

48
00:02:48.590 --> 00:02:51.735
So as close as you can,
you want to be able to do that.

49
00:02:51.735 --> 00:02:55.749
The reason why is that you always want
to take a look at whatever's gonna be

50
00:02:55.749 --> 00:02:59.700
captured when you do the analysis from
the standpoint of where the user is

51
00:02:59.700 --> 00:03:01.287
complaining about, okay?

52
00:03:01.287 --> 00:03:04.290
So you get their full
perspective on what's happening.

53
00:03:04.290 --> 00:03:08.450
If there are wireless, you want to come
down here and maybe run it on your own,

54
00:03:08.450 --> 00:03:11.144
and make sure you're
connecting in the same way.

55
00:03:11.144 --> 00:03:14.980
If they're wireless and you decide
to run it on a wired par network,

56
00:03:14.980 --> 00:03:19.041
not saying it won't work, okay,
you still might get the same issues.

57
00:03:19.041 --> 00:03:22.640
But you won't understand what
it is the issue actually is.

58
00:03:22.640 --> 00:03:27.260
So make sure you realize that, that at
some point here you wanna make sure that's

59
00:03:27.260 --> 00:03:31.050
it's as close to where the issue
is actually occurring is the key.

60
00:03:31.050 --> 00:03:33.610
>> What, Ronnie,
if this was an issue affecting many users?

61
00:03:33.610 --> 00:03:37.353
Such as, maybe I was experiencing echo or
jitter within a VoIP phone system,

62
00:03:37.353 --> 00:03:39.038
where would I place that utility?

63
00:03:39.038 --> 00:03:42.650
>> Well, that's one of those things
where you have to actually figure out,

64
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:44.468
is it happening to every user or not?

65
00:03:44.468 --> 00:03:45.751
>> On that segment.
>> Once you do,

66
00:03:45.751 --> 00:03:50.534
yep, you actually want to make sure then
at that point you can capture it on that

67
00:03:50.534 --> 00:03:53.310
particular segment that you want.

68
00:03:53.310 --> 00:03:55.350
Now, by doing that, how can you do that?

69
00:03:55.350 --> 00:03:58.090
There's a couple of options
that you have ahead of you.

70
00:03:58.090 --> 00:04:03.060
And we actually did talk about this in
our cyber security show that we did, but

71
00:04:03.060 --> 00:04:04.930
you have really two options.

72
00:04:04.930 --> 00:04:08.540
If that switch is something like
a Cisco switch, it makes sense.

73
00:04:08.540 --> 00:04:12.860
We can just simply run SPAN and
do that ability to do port mirroring.

74
00:04:12.860 --> 00:04:16.480
And try and say, hey, on this VLAN,
I wanna make sure for

75
00:04:16.480 --> 00:04:20.140
the voice traffic, right,
that all that also gets sent over.

76
00:04:20.140 --> 00:04:24.960
And I can run Wireshark on the device that
then all the packets that it possibly can

77
00:04:24.960 --> 00:04:29.990
is mirrored over to my particular
device that I'm running Wireshark on.

78
00:04:29.990 --> 00:04:31.964
>> Okay.
>> When you do something like that,

79
00:04:31.964 --> 00:04:34.807
that will work, but
you may also cause network slow down.

80
00:04:34.807 --> 00:04:38.893
And that's because you're causing that
switch to now have to generate duplicate

81
00:04:38.893 --> 00:04:40.200
copies, right?

82
00:04:40.200 --> 00:04:44.110
Of everything that's going across
every other port in that VLAN,

83
00:04:44.110 --> 00:04:45.570
sending it to one port.

84
00:04:45.570 --> 00:04:48.820
And it's gonna cause time
issues because it is,

85
00:04:48.820 --> 00:04:52.840
it's duplicating every bit of traffic
that it can and sending it over.

86
00:04:52.840 --> 00:04:55.414
You may also get dropped packets,
you may also do that.

87
00:04:55.414 --> 00:04:58.971
A better way, if possible,
if you can do this of course,

88
00:04:58.971 --> 00:05:03.980
may cost a bit more expense, but
it's to provide a network tap instead.

89
00:05:03.980 --> 00:05:06.646
Which doesn't cause any slow down.

90
00:05:06.646 --> 00:05:11.552
That's an inline device, in which you
now also plug into the switch itself,

91
00:05:11.552 --> 00:05:15.263
into that segment, and try and
capture the data that way.

92
00:05:15.263 --> 00:05:17.275
So that is a possibility.

93
00:05:17.275 --> 00:05:21.430
You wanna capture just about all the data
going across the network, usually.

94
00:05:21.430 --> 00:05:24.334
You can run it as close to
something like the firewall, or

95
00:05:24.334 --> 00:05:26.281
to your router as possible, as well.

96
00:05:26.281 --> 00:05:30.067
Now of course, in your branch offices
you may end up figuring out that for

97
00:05:30.067 --> 00:05:34.410
you to be able to get everything that
you need to in terms of capturing.

98
00:05:34.410 --> 00:05:39.310
You may find out where you do have
to run this in multiple locations.

99
00:05:39.310 --> 00:05:41.330
Not necessarily simultaneously.

100
00:05:41.330 --> 00:05:44.890
But to be able to get a picture of
everything that you need to get a nice,

101
00:05:44.890 --> 00:05:46.330
comprehensive picture.

102
00:05:46.330 --> 00:05:49.650
Placement is the key in
terms of packet capturing.

103
00:05:49.650 --> 00:05:52.450
And that's what we wanted to
make sure that we emphasize here

104
00:05:52.450 --> 00:05:54.820
right at the beginning, okay?

105
00:05:54.820 --> 00:05:59.170
So the great thing is now
that Wireshark is installed,

106
00:05:59.170 --> 00:06:03.470
that now means we can
perform a packet capture.

107
00:06:03.470 --> 00:06:06.449
And just when you think, it's easy enough,
I can see we just press a button and

108
00:06:06.449 --> 00:06:07.640
it starts capturing packets.

109
00:06:07.640 --> 00:06:09.510
Yeah, that's as easy as it gets.

110
00:06:09.510 --> 00:06:12.990
But there are some options that you and
I definitely need to consider.

111
00:06:12.990 --> 00:06:14.780
Especially in the newer version.

112
00:06:14.780 --> 00:06:17.597
Most of the older versions it's
been kinda the same format and

113
00:06:17.597 --> 00:06:19.660
layout that you've seen earlier.

114
00:06:19.660 --> 00:06:23.580
But now in the newer versions it's changed
up just a little bit beginning with 2.0.

115
00:06:23.580 --> 00:06:27.124
So in our particular version we're gonna
actually see some of these options that

116
00:06:27.124 --> 00:06:29.587
we're talking about when we
begin to capture packets.

117
00:06:29.587 --> 00:06:32.610
So let's switch on over to my machine now.

118
00:06:32.610 --> 00:06:33.475
And let's begin here, okay?

119
00:06:33.475 --> 00:06:38.985
So with my machine I want to launch
up Wireshark at the very beginning.

120
00:06:42.835 --> 00:06:48.297
And when I do so, I am brought to
this particular interface, right?

121
00:06:48.297 --> 00:06:53.870
And it's not glamorous, it's not exciting,
there's not a lot of color to this.

122
00:06:53.870 --> 00:06:55.680
But it really is as basic and

123
00:06:55.680 --> 00:06:58.520
as stripped down as it gets,
which tells you something here.

124
00:06:58.520 --> 00:07:02.210
That they're trying to, instead of
impress you with a bunch of graphics and

125
00:07:02.210 --> 00:07:07.080
trying to help you out by leading
you step by step on everything.

126
00:07:07.080 --> 00:07:10.550
They're really saying, if you want to
get started on the capture, it's simple.

127
00:07:10.550 --> 00:07:14.030
Take a look at the available
network adapters that you have.

128
00:07:14.030 --> 00:07:17.140
And, Cherokee, I don't know if you can,
I'm hoping you can see this.

129
00:07:17.140 --> 00:07:21.000
Cuz it really is small on my screen, but
I zoomed in so that we can see it here.

130
00:07:21.000 --> 00:07:24.550
But you can see that I have four
different network interfaces.

131
00:07:24.550 --> 00:07:25.980
>> Mm-hm.
>> And you might find that out.

132
00:07:25.980 --> 00:07:28.950
You might find out that your machine
that you're on does have multiple

133
00:07:28.950 --> 00:07:30.510
interfaces that are there.

134
00:07:30.510 --> 00:07:33.930
But it's relatively generic, but
you can see that right here,

135
00:07:33.930 --> 00:07:35.397
I only have one plugged in.

136
00:07:35.397 --> 00:07:35.978
>> Right.
>> And

137
00:07:35.978 --> 00:07:37.285
the way that you can tell
that is that little tiny-

138
00:07:37.285 --> 00:07:38.960
>> You see that traffic there.

139
00:07:38.960 --> 00:07:42.416
>> Yeah, that little tiny kind of
blip that's going across the screen.

00:07:42.416 --> 00:07:44.352

00:07:44.352 --> 00:07:48.536

00:07:48.536 --> 00:07:50.768
That would be better than any of one,

00:07:50.768 --> 00:07:51.870
>> There you go.
[LAUGH]

144
00:07:51.870 --> 00:07:52.800
>> At the same time,

145
00:07:52.800 --> 00:07:55.035
that would be something disconcerting for

146
00:07:55.035 --> 00:07:57.903
your doctor if your heart
rate looked like that at all.

147
00:07:57.903 --> 00:08:00.353
So here It's simple, right?

148
00:08:00.353 --> 00:08:03.964
You just select that and
you are off and you're ready to go.

149
00:08:03.964 --> 00:08:10.760
But in a real production environment, you
don't want to just do this all the time.

150
00:08:10.760 --> 00:08:11.660
You can, okay?

151
00:08:11.660 --> 00:08:13.390
It's probably not gonna hurt anything.

152
00:08:13.390 --> 00:08:16.390
But remember that when you
start doing this stuff live,

153
00:08:16.390 --> 00:08:20.120
you're only really getting a momentary
picture of what you're taking a look at.

154
00:08:20.120 --> 00:08:23.780
And there are more options that
are available that you should understand

155
00:08:23.780 --> 00:08:25.240
before you begin to capture.

156
00:08:25.240 --> 00:08:26.940
Now it doesn't mean you have to.

157
00:08:26.940 --> 00:08:30.310
You can simply run the capture and
go, okay, I'm done, no big deal.

158
00:08:30.310 --> 00:08:31.650
And that would be the end of our show.

159
00:08:31.650 --> 00:08:32.830
So have a good day.

160
00:08:32.830 --> 00:08:33.950

161
00:08:33.950 --> 00:08:35.266

Yeah, so what was the point?

162
00:08:35.266 --> 00:08:36.630
[LAUGH] So overall though.

163
00:08:36.630 --> 00:08:40.830
But that's that simple, it really
is that simple for us to do that.

164
00:08:40.830 --> 00:08:45.920
But there are options on these interfaces
that we definitely want to take a look at.

165
00:08:45.920 --> 00:08:52.050
So here on the, let me zoom in
a little bit, if I click on capture

166
00:08:52.050 --> 00:08:57.960
notice I have capture options and that is
key for what we want to have in place.

167
00:08:57.960 --> 00:09:02.740
If I select that, that will bring up
a nice little dialogue box window for us.

168
00:09:02.740 --> 00:09:06.880
And now we can see input
side as well as output side.

169
00:09:06.880 --> 00:09:09.500
And we'll talk about
the output here in a moment.

170
00:09:09.500 --> 00:09:13.170
But on the input,
we're starting to see which one of these.

171
00:09:13.170 --> 00:09:17.520
And the key, also, is making sure
that whatever mode that you're in.

172
00:09:17.520 --> 00:09:20.490
If you are unchecked on promiscuous mode,

173
00:09:20.490 --> 00:09:23.110
that's probably not a good thing
if you're doing a capture.

174
00:09:23.110 --> 00:09:26.300
But if you find out that you have
a network adapter and the promiscuous mode

175
00:09:26.300 --> 00:09:29.470
cannot be checked, more than likely
you're not gonna be able to capture data

176
00:09:29.470 --> 00:09:34.910
on that particular interface except for
what's being absolutely destined for you.

177
00:09:34.910 --> 00:09:36.810
As far as a destination address goes.

178
00:09:38.200 --> 00:09:44.430
Also, you can see where it gives you
what they call a two megabyte buffer.

179
00:09:44.430 --> 00:09:49.930
So, this one, on the interface, it will
buffer up to two megabytes of text which

180
00:09:49.930 --> 00:09:53.830
is quite a bit of text that comes in.

181
00:09:53.830 --> 00:09:58.063
And the reason why we want to know is
that everything we're seeing, right,

182
00:09:58.063 --> 00:10:02.709
our display, or our graphics card may not
be as fast as what this spinning out here.

183
00:10:02.709 --> 00:10:07.780
So it can buffer a bit before we get into
what you're seeing there, all right?

184
00:10:07.780 --> 00:10:11.719
Now, let's go ahead and take a look at the
options here, and then we'll go back for

185
00:10:11.719 --> 00:10:13.367
the output here for just a moment.

186
00:10:15.566 --> 00:10:17.698
All right, so
let's take a look at the options, and

187
00:10:17.698 --> 00:10:19.550
we'll do it in the order
that they show here.

188
00:10:19.550 --> 00:10:22.270
Because it probably makes a little
bit more sense to work this way.

189
00:10:23.320 --> 00:10:25.870
We can have what we call Display Options,
okay?

190
00:10:25.870 --> 00:10:29.100
Display Options are very important
depending on what you need.

191
00:10:29.100 --> 00:10:33.600
Notice it says,
Update list of packets in real-time.

192
00:10:33.600 --> 00:10:37.870
Well, that means that as
the packets are coming in, and

193
00:10:37.870 --> 00:10:42.210
I have it also displaying in my screen
on the capture filter, I'm saying,

194
00:10:42.210 --> 00:10:44.750
as soon as it updates make sure
you also make a display of it.

195
00:10:44.750 --> 00:10:48.130
Well, that means it's gonna take
up more system resources to

196
00:10:48.130 --> 00:10:49.780
do something like this.

197
00:10:49.780 --> 00:10:54.120
So even though this is nice when I'm
doing something live and in real time for

198
00:10:54.120 --> 00:10:58.330
a brief amount of time I don't
necessarily have to do this.

199
00:10:58.330 --> 00:11:01.673
If I know that I'm gonna be
capturing the data and saving it for

200
00:11:01.673 --> 00:11:05.145
something a little bit later on,
okay I can just turn that off and

201
00:11:05.145 --> 00:11:08.838
not worry about what's being
displayed right there in front of me.

202
00:11:08.838 --> 00:11:13.337
And that will instead save some time for
what else is going to be happening and

203
00:11:13.337 --> 00:11:18.070
be able to save some computer cycles
instead of sending it to the screen.

204
00:11:18.070 --> 00:11:20.680
It just sends it on to
where I want it to go.

205
00:11:20.680 --> 00:11:24.280
Also notice the automatically
scroll during live capture.

206
00:11:24.280 --> 00:11:28.420
This is what we'll see when we do the
capture where the data will look like it's

207
00:11:28.420 --> 00:11:30.314
just scrolling across the screen.

208
00:11:30.314 --> 00:11:34.415
Once again that has to go
through the CPU processor itself

209
00:11:34.415 --> 00:11:38.970
which means it's taking
up more cycles on things.

210
00:11:38.970 --> 00:11:40.850
And doesn't necessarily have to do that.

211
00:11:40.850 --> 00:11:43.260
But you wanna see it,
that's what you have there too.

212
00:11:43.260 --> 00:11:45.870
And then of course,
extra capture information dialog.

213
00:11:45.870 --> 00:11:51.150
A lot of times when you do end up
capturing data, normally you can hover

214
00:11:51.150 --> 00:11:56.180
over a particular packet and it will give
you a little tool tip that will display.

215
00:11:56.180 --> 00:11:59.400
If you don't need that, well again,
just uncheck that if you don't want to.

216
00:12:00.410 --> 00:12:04.470
Now the big part of something else, and
you've seen that a lot of this as far as

217
00:12:04.470 --> 00:12:08.550
the options go, it really is about
performance more than anything else too.

218
00:12:08.550 --> 00:12:11.970
The same thing with name
resolution as a big part.

219
00:12:11.970 --> 00:12:15.670
The only one that they have checked here
out of the three options that we have

220
00:12:15.670 --> 00:12:17.960
is of course just the MAC address.

221
00:12:17.960 --> 00:12:19.970
The reason why is because that's a fairly

222
00:12:21.990 --> 00:12:24.760
limited in comparison to
the other two options, right?

223
00:12:24.760 --> 00:12:28.080
When you take a look at the MAC address,
which is a 48-bit

224
00:12:28.080 --> 00:12:32.450
binary address all together,
reported in hexadecimal, normally.

225
00:12:32.450 --> 00:12:36.750
One of the first 24 bits
are vendor identifiers, right?

226
00:12:36.750 --> 00:12:40.990
So let's say that there
are 20,000 vendors out there.

227
00:12:40.990 --> 00:12:43.200
I don't even know how many that there are.

228
00:12:43.200 --> 00:12:47.300
But that's just really a static
list of 20,000 vendors, right?

229
00:12:47.300 --> 00:12:52.070
So when they look that up, they can
actually say, this is an Intel NIC, or

230
00:12:52.070 --> 00:12:56.230
this is a Broadcom or
a Dell or HP, whatever it is.

231
00:12:56.230 --> 00:12:59.520
Fairly quickly because that's
the fairly small list in comparison.

232
00:12:59.520 --> 00:13:04.940
So they can resolve the name of the net
very easily, very quickly from a fairly

233
00:13:04.940 --> 00:13:11.630
small list but notice these other two
here, as far as the network names go.

234
00:13:11.630 --> 00:13:16.392
Well every network name
in theory can be unique.

235
00:13:16.392 --> 00:13:21.597
Not everybody does kind of
the standard very drab naming

236
00:13:21.597 --> 00:13:27.010
convention like I do,
Client01 and Client02.

237
00:13:27.010 --> 00:13:31.000
Some people are very creative and they
can name every single one differently.

238
00:13:31.000 --> 00:13:34.560
Well remember if that happens,
what has to happen here right.

239
00:13:34.560 --> 00:13:37.670
Is gonna be some type of
reverse look up right?

240
00:13:37.670 --> 00:13:41.680
For DNS, that's when we take a name,
and we resolve it to an IP address.

241
00:13:41.680 --> 00:13:45.550
But, a reverse look up, right, takes
an IP address, which is what comes in

242
00:13:45.550 --> 00:13:50.390
on the capture itself, and
resolves a name for us instead.

243
00:13:50.390 --> 00:13:52.870
Well, that's what this is doing, okay?

244
00:13:52.870 --> 00:13:55.970
And if it has to actually look it up,
it means it has to go and ask somebody,

245
00:13:55.970 --> 00:13:56.950
if it doesn't know what it is.

246
00:13:56.950 --> 00:14:00.120
And that has to do it for every single
name that comes across the network.

247
00:14:01.370 --> 00:14:04.875
>> Now Ronnie, these settings aren't
really set in stone, so to speak.

248
00:14:04.875 --> 00:14:08.208
Because I've noticed some of them,
especially on the left-hand side,

00:14:08.208 --> 00:14:11.100
where you see the automatically
scroll during live.

250
00:14:11.100 --> 00:14:15.290
The actual interface has the ability for
you to pause and stop that scrolling.

251
00:14:15.290 --> 00:14:18.190
But we can come back and
change these at other times too, right?

252
00:14:18.190 --> 00:14:19.520

In other words, just block it.

00:25:44.540 --> 00:25:47.500
Don't send it into Wireshark itself.

481
00:25:47.500 --> 00:25:50.540
Now, you might go, yeah,
that's the way to go.

482
00:25:50.540 --> 00:25:53.920
It is, except that that can be
a performance hindrance as well,

483
00:25:53.920 --> 00:25:56.710
because it's saying make the decision,

484
00:25:56.710 --> 00:26:00.630
here's the stuff that I want you to
not actually even try and capture.

485
00:26:00.630 --> 00:26:02.880
Well, what does it have to do to do that?

486
00:26:02.880 --> 00:26:03.920
Has to detect it first.

487
00:26:03.920 --> 00:26:08.340
So if it detects it, you're saying
detect it, drop it, don't send it in.

488
00:26:08.340 --> 00:26:10.107
But a display filter though.

489
00:26:12.812 --> 00:26:14.775
[SOUND] I did it again, all right,

490
00:26:14.775 --> 00:26:18.153
let me just close that out
before I get in trouble, okay?

491
00:26:18.153 --> 00:26:21.890
A display filter though, is different.

492
00:26:21.890 --> 00:26:26.828
A display filter says, look I'm taking
all of it in, just like a regular packet

493
00:26:26.828 --> 00:26:30.531
sniffer would do, but
then if I want to display something.

494
00:26:30.531 --> 00:26:34.274
So, let's say ARP here
cuz that's actually easy.

495
00:26:34.274 --> 00:26:36.250
Now it didn't say what?

496
00:26:36.250 --> 00:26:39.004
Don't send it into it, but just do what?

497
00:26:39.004 --> 00:26:40.851
>> Filter it.
>> Just filter out the display.

498
00:26:40.851 --> 00:26:43.290
This one is much faster, okay?

499
00:26:43.290 --> 00:26:47.950
So, the recommendation, the best practice,
even from the lady that actually does

500
00:26:47.950 --> 00:26:52.760
a lot of teaching on Wireshark,
says use display filters a lot.

501
00:26:52.760 --> 00:26:55.690
Use capture filters sparingly.

502
00:26:55.690 --> 00:26:57.670
Not saying you can't do it, but

503
00:26:57.670 --> 00:27:00.980
just kinda realize that they are two
different options that are available.

504
00:27:00.980 --> 00:27:03.990
And this depends on the performance
that you need at the time.

505
00:27:03.990 --> 00:27:05.578
Most of the time we're
on a hurry to do this.

506
00:27:05.578 --> 00:27:08.743
But it does, you have to kinda slow
down before you can get faster.

507
00:27:08.743 --> 00:27:13.379
And that is also a key here too in terms
of what we are actually capturing at

508
00:27:13.379 --> 00:27:14.219
this point.

509
00:27:14.219 --> 00:27:18.123
Now, once you get that of course,
it means we need now to go all right, so

510
00:27:18.123 --> 00:27:19.852
now that all this data's here,

511
00:27:19.852 --> 00:27:23.971
remember that the data in its natural
form doesn't look like this, right?

512
00:27:23.971 --> 00:27:27.554
The closest that it really looks like
to you and I is that little, tiny,

513
00:27:27.554 --> 00:27:31.094
squiggly line that we saw that
Cherokee said looked like a heartbeat.

514
00:27:31.094 --> 00:27:34.766
It really does,
it's really more of a signal form.

515
00:27:34.766 --> 00:27:38.230
But this is what Wireshark,
right, in terms of the capture.

516
00:27:38.230 --> 00:27:41.954
It not only captures that, it then
does that packet analysis, it says,

517
00:27:41.954 --> 00:27:45.328
let's put it into something that
makes it easier to understand.

518
00:27:45.328 --> 00:27:46.816
At least this point here.

519
00:27:46.816 --> 00:27:51.521
That is what you're seeing the capture
of all the data right here, but

520
00:27:51.521 --> 00:27:56.093
post it in a way that makes a little
bit more sense to us to what we see.

521
00:27:56.093 --> 00:27:59.415
>> Could you imagine if they just
left that third field at the bottom?

522
00:27:59.415 --> 00:28:01.649
And then had you sift through
the binary information?

523
00:28:01.649 --> 00:28:03.461
And that's how the computers see it,

524
00:28:03.461 --> 00:28:07.034
so yeah, that would be a lot of work to
try to figure out what was happening.

525
00:28:07.034 --> 00:28:07.900
>> That's true, yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

526
00:28:07.900 --> 00:28:09.375
>> Once you start seeing ascii code and

527
00:28:09.375 --> 00:28:13.255
the hex code here, you better believe it
it becomes a little bit more challenging.

528
00:28:13.255 --> 00:28:16.010
But the great thing is it
does interpret it for us.

529
00:28:16.010 --> 00:28:19.508
And that is when we actually need to
do a little bit more of the packet

530
00:28:19.508 --> 00:28:20.388
analysis part.

531
00:28:20.388 --> 00:28:24.179
But at least on the capture part, you've
gone through some of those different

532
00:28:24.179 --> 00:28:25.910
options that are available to you.

533
00:28:25.910 --> 00:28:28.463
You understand
the importance of placement,

534
00:28:28.463 --> 00:28:31.740
which you'll know better
because it's your own network.

535
00:28:31.740 --> 00:28:35.311
Rather than mine,
the single one that I drew up here.

536
00:28:35.311 --> 00:28:37.835
And you'll actually kind of be able
to play around and understand.

537
00:28:37.835 --> 00:28:41.531
But always remember that
when you're trying to do

538
00:28:41.531 --> 00:28:45.500
this as far as a real issue
solving tool goes, right?

539
00:28:45.500 --> 00:28:49.520
You want to place as close as you can
to the person that's experiencing

540
00:28:49.520 --> 00:28:52.615
the difficulties or saying that
they're experiencing the difficulties.

541
00:28:52.615 --> 00:28:55.129
Cuz you want to always see
it from that perspective.

542
00:28:55.129 --> 00:28:56.649
It is easy to make a judgement,
and go nope.

543
00:28:56.649 --> 00:28:59.201
Well, from where I am
everything looks great.

544
00:28:59.201 --> 00:29:02.457
Well, that's great but from where they
are it may not look the same way.

545
00:29:02.457 --> 00:29:04.473
So make sure you take that in hand, and

546
00:29:04.473 --> 00:29:06.957
you can begin just
capturing the data as well.

547
00:29:06.957 --> 00:29:09.265
Now, of course we are not
gonna leave you there,okay?

548
00:29:09.265 --> 00:29:13.420
We are gonna start taking a look at
the data that we've also captured as well.

549
00:29:13.420 --> 00:29:14.890
And try and make some semblance and

550
00:29:14.890 --> 00:29:18.020
understanding of that and
apply some more filters to it, and

551
00:29:18.020 --> 00:29:22.480
that's really kind of the more powerful
nature of what we see Wireshark doing.

552
00:29:22.480 --> 00:29:24.620
But here is, at least, the very beginning.

553
00:29:24.620 --> 00:29:26.790
Which is understanding the capture and

554
00:29:26.790 --> 00:29:31.000
options that are available,
so make sure you start there.

555
00:29:31.000 --> 00:29:32.920
>> There really are a lot
of different options.

556
00:29:32.920 --> 00:29:35.450
And thank you for taking the time
to show us that today Ronnie.

557
00:29:35.450 --> 00:29:37.930
And I think for you guys,
if you're at home or

558
00:29:37.930 --> 00:29:41.600
at work, the best thing to do at
this point in time, go ahead and

559
00:29:41.600 --> 00:29:43.480
examine those different options,
even the interface.

560
00:29:43.480 --> 00:29:46.200
You're able to change the look,
the layout, the feel.

561
00:29:46.200 --> 00:29:48.270
And you saw all those options
that Ronnie showed you, so

562
00:29:48.270 --> 00:29:50.450
take the time to really just dig in there.

563
00:29:50.450 --> 00:29:53.400
But we do, like Ronnie said,
have more information headed your way, so

564
00:29:53.400 --> 00:29:53.990
stay tuned.

565
00:29:53.990 --> 00:29:56.790
But for this show,
we are gonna go ahead and sign out.

566
00:29:56.790 --> 00:29:58.540
Remember, I'm your show
host Cherokee Boose.

567
00:29:58.540 --> 00:29:59.490
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

568
00:29:59.490 --> 00:30:02.164
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

569
00:30:02.164 --> 00:30:08.168
[MUSIC]

570
00:30:08.168 --> 00:30:11.464
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Navigating the Wireshark interface may be a little intimidating but Ronnie and Cherokee lessen that sting and demonstrate several settings to ease your experience. First, Ronnie breaks down the basic layout of the default profile then proceeds to demonstrate how to create custom profiles.
episodes.title: Use Wireshark Interface
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:06.274
Welcome to ITPro.TV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.274 --> 00:00:08.184
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.184 --> 00:00:12.026
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.026 --> 00:00:14.200
>> Welcome to your Wireshark show.

5
00:00:14.200 --> 00:00:15.570
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.770 --> 00:00:20.490
In this episode we'll be looking at
how to use the Wireshark interface.

7
00:00:20.490 --> 00:00:23.170
With us today we have Mr.
Ronnie Wong to help

8
00:00:23.170 --> 00:00:26.060
decipher all the different buttons and
gadgets in the layout.

9
00:00:26.060 --> 00:00:27.420
Thank you for joining us today.

10
00:00:27.420 --> 00:00:28.140
>> Well thank you for

11
00:00:28.140 --> 00:00:31.480
having me back as we continue to learn
a little bit more about Wireshark.

12
00:00:31.480 --> 00:00:32.810
Getting started.

13
00:00:32.810 --> 00:00:37.182
Where we picked up on or where we left
from last time is that we really showed

14
00:00:37.182 --> 00:00:39.800
you how to do the basics
of a packet capture.

15
00:00:39.800 --> 00:00:42.526
And I know I probably said
the term data capture.

16
00:00:42.526 --> 00:00:44.294
I probably use them interchangeably.

17
00:00:44.294 --> 00:00:48.070
But if your having technical
difficulties understand that.

18
00:00:48.070 --> 00:00:49.540
I really meant the idea of packet capture.

19
00:00:49.540 --> 00:00:52.330
Which is kinda of the correct
technical term here.

20
00:00:52.330 --> 00:00:55.890
But overall though, we really just
showed you how to do a basic capture.

21
00:00:55.890 --> 00:00:59.060
Remember that when you capture all
the information, you now have a chance,

22
00:00:59.060 --> 00:01:02.400
of course,
to have a display inside of WireShark.

23
00:01:02.400 --> 00:01:04.553
But if you're brand new
to using WireShark,

24
00:01:04.553 --> 00:01:08.021
it might be a little bit hard to
understand what you're taking a look at.

25
00:01:08.021 --> 00:01:09.809
And I tried to not focus in on that,

26
00:01:09.809 --> 00:01:13.020
cuz I knew we were gonna do
an entire episode on this.

27
00:01:13.020 --> 00:01:15.610
So that's why I wanted to
kind of a skip over that.

28
00:01:15.610 --> 00:01:19.780
So I was trying to lead you away from
focusing in too much on the details, and

29
00:01:19.780 --> 00:01:23.060
just focussing in on what we wanted to
which was you can start a basic capture.

30
00:01:23.060 --> 00:01:27.156
Just about anybody can, and now we
are going to take a look at why this is

31
00:01:27.156 --> 00:01:29.942
important and
what the breakdown actually is.

32
00:01:29.942 --> 00:01:34.356
And also of course how we can customize
it to make it more usable for

33
00:01:34.356 --> 00:01:37.530
what we want to do each and every day.

34
00:01:37.530 --> 00:01:38.430
So the great thing is,

35
00:01:38.430 --> 00:01:42.150
we can get started right away by
simply taking a look at my machine.

36
00:01:42.150 --> 00:01:44.390
And that way we'll get started here, okay?

37
00:01:44.390 --> 00:01:45.970
Remember that in every
version of Wireshark,

38
00:01:45.970 --> 00:01:51.455
whether you're running it on Mac or
on Windows, it'll look fairly similar.

39
00:01:51.455 --> 00:01:54.035
I'm not gonna say, well,
it will always look identical.

40
00:01:54.035 --> 00:01:55.942
So, I'm just gonna stick
with the Windows interface,

41
00:01:55.942 --> 00:01:58.839
because that's probably the majority of
us that's using Wireshark at this point.

42
00:01:58.839 --> 00:01:59.655
>> All right.

43
00:01:59.655 --> 00:02:04.365
>> But, let's go ahead and start
taking that idea of the capture first.

44
00:02:04.365 --> 00:02:07.965
Remember that, for us,
we are going to capture based on data.

45
00:02:07.965 --> 00:02:13.060
And this is the only interface that I see
a little bit of blip of data going across.

46
00:02:13.060 --> 00:02:17.660
Now, I kinda emphasized this in our
last episode where I showed you.

47
00:02:17.660 --> 00:02:19.540
And I said in all reality, right?

48
00:02:19.540 --> 00:02:24.670
This is really representation of what is
coming across the interface its self.

49
00:02:24.670 --> 00:02:28.926
Which is just a bunch of blips or
electrical signals that come across.

50
00:02:28.926 --> 00:02:32.734
But I also wanna show you something else,
let me close out of Wireshark for

51
00:02:32.734 --> 00:02:34.650
a moment and then I'll relaunch it.

52
00:02:37.840 --> 00:02:40.994
Now the reason why I'm doing this is
I want us to pay attention to some of

53
00:02:40.994 --> 00:02:44.042
the words that are scrolling by,
right when I relaunch Wireshark,

54
00:02:44.042 --> 00:02:45.825
if it actually ever comes back up here.

55
00:02:45.825 --> 00:02:49.203
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is right here in the middle,

56
00:02:49.203 --> 00:02:51.820
notice where it says
registering dissectors.

57
00:02:51.820 --> 00:02:54.744
>> Yes.
>> Okay, dissectors is kind of the key

58
00:02:54.744 --> 00:02:59.369
element, is kind of where we see
the power of Wireshark coming in.

59
00:02:59.369 --> 00:03:04.304
And what I mean by that is that, is there
inside of the core engine of Wireshark,

60
00:03:04.304 --> 00:03:09.560
that it takes all of the signal that's
coming across the network interface.

61
00:03:09.560 --> 00:03:11.080
And then changes it to a,

62
00:03:11.080 --> 00:03:16.020
I don't wanna say change it, represents
that signal in stuff that you and

63
00:03:16.020 --> 00:03:21.460
I will have a chance at least visibly
to understand and also be able

64
00:03:21.460 --> 00:03:25.580
to make some details of it, in other words
to make it a little bit more meaningful.

65
00:03:25.580 --> 00:03:26.960
But when it does it,

66
00:03:26.960 --> 00:03:31.330
it reports it in three separate
fashions at the very beginning.

67
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:34.320
So that's what I wanna do,
to make sure that we understand.

68
00:03:34.320 --> 00:03:37.560
So when you see the loading of the
dissectors there, that's what it's doing.

69
00:03:37.560 --> 00:03:41.120
It's saying, here's all the ways that
we can take whatever's coming in, and

70
00:03:41.120 --> 00:03:46.200
put it into different locations and
places dissecting the data so

71
00:03:46.200 --> 00:03:48.810
that we understand what
it really means for us.

72
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:51.460
So, let me take that Ethernet 0 again and

73
00:03:51.460 --> 00:03:53.770
I'm simply gonna double-click
on the interface.

74
00:03:53.770 --> 00:03:57.920
And now, notice here is pretty
much what we call a default look.

75
00:03:57.920 --> 00:04:00.660
Now, how do I know that this
is the default profile?

76
00:04:00.660 --> 00:04:02.740
Well, if I take a look in
the lower right-hand corner,

77
00:04:02.740 --> 00:04:04.670
let me float down over here.

78
00:04:04.670 --> 00:04:08.225
I'll actually see that it tells me,
let me see if I can zoom in there.

79
00:04:08.225 --> 00:04:10.530
It says Profile Default.

80
00:04:10.530 --> 00:04:14.760
So there is going to be this view
that we end up seeing right here,

81
00:04:14.760 --> 00:04:19.630
that tells us, here's the basic
stuff that we're looking at.

82
00:04:19.630 --> 00:04:23.183
So in the Wireshark layout that you see,
we can take a look at a lot,

83
00:04:23.183 --> 00:04:26.920
and what we're gonna focus in on
of course is the main interface.

84
00:04:26.920 --> 00:04:30.390
But let's go through just some details
right here at the very beginning.

85
00:04:30.390 --> 00:04:34.980
Up at the top is just a regular,
standard type of menu system, that you

86
00:04:34.980 --> 00:04:39.370
have available to you, and anything
that you can do in Wireshark of course.

87
00:04:39.370 --> 00:04:41.010
You'll come up here to the menu and

88
00:04:41.010 --> 00:04:45.270
you can start using all these
different things that are available.

89
00:04:45.270 --> 00:04:49.740
Now, some of these go beyond my skill set,
such as all the telephony stuff.

90
00:04:49.740 --> 00:04:52.700
I don't know anything about telephony,
when it comes down to it.

91
00:04:52.700 --> 00:04:57.190
Wireless, I can kind of handle, and,
of course, some of the networking stuff.

92
00:04:57.190 --> 00:04:57.930
But overall,

93
00:04:57.930 --> 00:05:02.100
though, anything that you can do, this
is every tool that's available for you.

94
00:05:02.100 --> 00:05:06.830
As you start using Wireshark more and
more, you are going to be, depend less on

95
00:05:06.830 --> 00:05:10.540
trying to find everything, and
notice that they have another toolbar for

96
00:05:10.540 --> 00:05:14.130
us, which is really kind of
the quick start type of toolbar.

97
00:05:14.130 --> 00:05:19.020
If I want to begin a capture on a packet,
I could just have it default to here and

98
00:05:19.020 --> 00:05:20.380
just click on the little shark fin,

99
00:05:20.380 --> 00:05:23.300
and notice it will start it,
I can stop a capture.

100
00:05:23.300 --> 00:05:26.630
I can even restart a current capture,
if I want to.

101
00:05:26.630 --> 00:05:27.700
And of course I have options and

102
00:05:27.700 --> 00:05:31.630
most of these are grayed out because I'm
in the middle of a capture currently, so

103
00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:34.480
I don't have any way of
changing some of this stuff.

104
00:05:34.480 --> 00:05:36.580
But you can continue
to go through here and

105
00:05:36.580 --> 00:05:39.030
see some of these different utilities and
tools.

106
00:05:39.030 --> 00:05:42.750
One of the neat ones for us right,
so let's say that you can't see it,

107
00:05:42.750 --> 00:05:47.330
I know that by default on Wireshark
the font is really small.

108
00:05:47.330 --> 00:05:51.604
Notice that they have these two
little magnifying glasses, right?

109
00:05:51.604 --> 00:05:52.590
>> Very helpful.

110
00:05:52.590 --> 00:05:56.258
>> If I select that plus sign,
you can now see where I can, look at that!

111
00:05:56.258 --> 00:06:01.200
That'll actually scroll in a little bit so
that we can see it a little bit better.

112
00:06:01.200 --> 00:06:03.569
So that's great for guys like me,
whose eyesights are incredibly terrible.

113
00:06:03.569 --> 00:06:07.998
>> [LAUGH] I know, some of the people here
probably make fun of me because I say I

114
00:06:07.998 --> 00:06:11.713
don't wanna wear my glasses
because I might seem like a nerd,

115
00:06:11.713 --> 00:06:12.398
but
>> Yeah.

116
00:06:12.398 --> 00:06:14.690
[LAUGH]
>> Go figure, right?

117
00:06:14.690 --> 00:06:15.240
>> So there it is.

118
00:06:15.240 --> 00:06:19.710
I'm zoomed all the way out to
kind of the normal 100% of view.

119
00:06:19.710 --> 00:06:21.130
If I now click on that plus sign,

120
00:06:21.130 --> 00:06:24.812
notice I can make that look just
a little bit easier on the screen there.

121
00:06:24.812 --> 00:06:26.540
So I don't always have to zoom in, but

122
00:06:26.540 --> 00:06:29.710
notice the rest of the menu bar
doesn't actually zoom in for me.

123
00:06:29.710 --> 00:06:34.150
I'm gonna just put it back down to what
I believe is close to that 100% mark.

124
00:06:34.150 --> 00:06:36.210
I may actually be off just a little bit.

125
00:06:36.210 --> 00:06:39.225
But that'll make it work for
what we want to do, okay?

126
00:06:39.225 --> 00:06:41.170
So that's fairly easy.

127
00:06:41.170 --> 00:06:44.340
From that point, I have,
of course, a display filter.

128
00:06:44.340 --> 00:06:47.050
Now we're gonna get into
display filters and

129
00:06:47.050 --> 00:06:51.210
capture filters in the next show,
our next episode or so.
