since Cherokee mentioned another laptop,

354
00:19:19.160 --> 00:19:22.670
it doesn't mean that she has to go and
create the profiles on the other laptop.

355
00:19:22.670 --> 00:19:27.790
She can also end up taking the file where
the profiles are, because they're simple

356
00:19:27.790 --> 00:19:33.580
text files, copying them into the root
folder where those profiles reside.

357
00:19:33.580 --> 00:19:37.400
And now, even on her other laptop,
she can have those same profiles that

358
00:19:37.400 --> 00:19:40.830
are traveling with her,
even on another laptop.

359
00:19:40.830 --> 00:19:43.290
So it really can be very helpful, and

360
00:19:43.290 --> 00:19:46.640
it is something that we should at
least understand the basics of,

361
00:19:46.640 --> 00:19:50.250
as we go through and
take a look at doing what we need to do.

362
00:19:50.250 --> 00:19:51.370
>> So we're gonna be looking at this?

363
00:19:51.370 --> 00:19:53.050
>> We are gonna show you
to how to create a profile.

364
00:19:53.050 --> 00:19:53.859
>> Awesome.
>> That's what we're gonna do.

365
00:19:53.859 --> 00:19:55.482
So I'm not gonna do
anything super fancy here.

366
00:19:55.482 --> 00:19:56.147
>> I haven't done that.

367
00:19:56.147 --> 00:19:59.229
>> But at least at the very beginning
we'll take a look at doing this,

368
00:19:59.229 --> 00:19:59.790
all right?

369
00:19:59.790 --> 00:20:03.700
So let's go ahead and
take a look at creating a profile.

370
00:20:03.700 --> 00:20:06.519
Here, as far as I know,
is the default profile.

371
00:20:06.519 --> 00:20:11.050
And the way that I can always verify
that is in the lower right-hand corner.

372
00:20:11.050 --> 00:20:15.860
Now, it's strange, I didn't really
find the option in the menu.

373
00:20:15.860 --> 00:20:19.420
Cuz I thought, of course they probably
put it up in the menu by this point.

374
00:20:19.420 --> 00:20:21.790
>> But no,
it's still in the lower right-hand corner.

375
00:20:21.790 --> 00:20:24.500
So what we want to do is, want to
right-click in the lower right-hand

376
00:20:24.500 --> 00:20:28.300
corner, and notice I have three
options that are highlighted.

377
00:20:28.300 --> 00:20:32.320
Let me see if I can zoom in to make
them a little bit better for us to see.

378
00:20:32.320 --> 00:20:33.260
There we go.

379
00:20:33.260 --> 00:20:36.280
We have Manage Profiles, we have New, and

380
00:20:36.280 --> 00:20:39.820
we have the ability to
Switch to another profile.

381
00:20:39.820 --> 00:20:43.690
Now, right now currently there
are three profiles, okay?

382
00:20:43.690 --> 00:20:48.650
So if I select Manage Profiles,
zoom out just a little bit,

383
00:20:48.650 --> 00:20:53.250
you can see where it's the Default, and
then there's one based on Bluetooth, and

384
00:20:53.250 --> 00:20:55.040
one that is called Classic here.

385
00:20:56.040 --> 00:21:00.450
Very important if you ever want to
copy them, is to know the location

386
00:21:00.450 --> 00:21:04.330
of where this profile folder is,
on your machine especially.

387
00:21:04.330 --> 00:21:07.100
Because if you wanna copy these profiles,
look at that,

388
00:21:07.100 --> 00:21:10.355
it actually says,
Program Files\Wireshark\profiles.

389
00:21:10.355 --> 00:21:11.960
>> Mm-hm.
>> And then you do this.

390
00:21:11.960 --> 00:21:14.368
If Cherokee wanted to
create her networking ones,

391
00:21:14.368 --> 00:21:16.727
she could actually call
it Cherokee Networking.

392
00:21:16.727 --> 00:21:21.576
And then as she creates that profile it's
gonna create a file right there in those

393
00:21:21.576 --> 00:21:22.860
locations.

394
00:21:22.860 --> 00:21:24.319
Then she can copy that and
go to a different

395
00:21:24.319 --> 00:21:25.239
>> Just import it to another system.

396
00:21:25.239 --> 00:21:25.861
>> Import it to another system.

397
00:21:25.861 --> 00:21:26.489
>> Very cool.

398
00:21:26.489 --> 00:21:28.610
>> And you're ready to go, okay?

399
00:21:28.610 --> 00:21:33.010
So it really is kind of helpful in
some of the things that you can do.

400
00:21:33.010 --> 00:21:36.170
But the switch between them,
that is the key right?

401
00:21:36.170 --> 00:21:38.470
If you know that you're gonna be
troubleshooting some of the different

402
00:21:38.470 --> 00:21:41.930
things, or I don't like this default view,
I can select Classic.

403
00:21:41.930 --> 00:21:45.380
And now you can see it doesn't
really look a lot different, but

404
00:21:45.380 --> 00:21:48.100
look at how small everything is too.

405
00:21:48.100 --> 00:21:49.820
So this changes everything for you.

406
00:21:49.820 --> 00:21:53.460
So this is what they call the Classic
view instead, that gives you

407
00:21:53.460 --> 00:21:58.310
all the information that they want instead
of whatever the default was set to.

408
00:21:58.310 --> 00:22:01.477
If I right-click on the Profile in
the lower right-hand corner again and

409
00:22:01.477 --> 00:22:03.740
I switch back to Default,
well, there you go.

410
00:22:03.740 --> 00:22:07.560
It changes, everything's back to
the way that I originally had it set.

411
00:22:07.560 --> 00:22:12.700
The key, at least best practice probably
is, don't mess with the Default profile.

412
00:22:12.700 --> 00:22:13.270
But can you?

413
00:22:13.270 --> 00:22:14.040
Yes, okay.

414
00:22:14.040 --> 00:22:16.750
If you wanna change it, and
you don't care what anybody else thinks-

415
00:22:16.750 --> 00:22:17.707
>> Create a custom profile and

416
00:22:17.707 --> 00:22:18.500
then modify that one.

417
00:22:18.500 --> 00:22:19.150
>> That's right, yeah.

418
00:22:19.150 --> 00:22:21.510
Create it, use this as a template,
and then modify it.

419
00:22:21.510 --> 00:22:22.890
And that's what we're gonna do.

420
00:22:22.890 --> 00:22:25.360
So let's take a look in the lower
right-hand corner again.

421
00:22:25.360 --> 00:22:29.230
And then I'm gonna right-click
on Profile and select New.

422
00:22:29.230 --> 00:22:32.550
When I do this,
I've got a couple of different things.

423
00:22:32.550 --> 00:22:37.050
But notice that even from the New,
it's asking me for a New profile name,

424
00:22:37.050 --> 00:22:40.510
it says Created from the default settings.

425
00:22:40.510 --> 00:22:42.883
So it essentially copied the default and
now is saying,

426
00:22:42.883 --> 00:22:45.040
let's give this a new name for right now.

427
00:22:45.040 --> 00:22:48.630
And we'll call this one,
like we said, Troubleshooting.

428
00:22:48.630 --> 00:22:50.734
Or actually, let's do ITProTV.

429
00:22:56.958 --> 00:22:57.998
>> You're changing your mind?

430
00:22:57.998 --> 00:22:59.894
>> Yeah, I hate doing that but
I do it anyways.

431
00:22:59.894 --> 00:23:03.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we'll just call it ITProTV.

432
00:23:03.740 --> 00:23:05.050
On that point I click OK.

433
00:23:06.390 --> 00:23:10.120
Once I do that, I need to verify
that I have selected that profile.

434
00:23:10.120 --> 00:23:12.349
So down in the lower
right-hand corner again,

435
00:23:12.349 --> 00:23:15.380
you'll see right here
where it says ITProTV.

436
00:23:15.380 --> 00:23:17.290
At least I think that's what it says.

437
00:23:17.290 --> 00:23:18.380
Yup, ITProTV.

438
00:23:19.390 --> 00:23:24.670
So now I can start modifying my
particular profile if I want to.

439
00:23:24.670 --> 00:23:27.750
So at this point, there's a couple
of things that we may choose to do,

440
00:23:27.750 --> 00:23:29.240
such as the size.

441
00:23:29.240 --> 00:23:33.148
I may choose to go ahead and
enlarge the font size.

442
00:23:35.026 --> 00:23:41.050
Also, I can come up here to,
where is my Tools there?

443
00:23:41.050 --> 00:23:45.190
Not Tools,
the colors is what I'm looking for.

444
00:23:45.190 --> 00:23:46.690
Let me see where I can, there it is.

445
00:23:46.690 --> 00:23:48.072
I was hoping to actually find the colors.

446
00:23:51.886 --> 00:23:54.978
And I can find the color,
well, no I can't.

447
00:23:54.978 --> 00:23:55.778
There we go.

448
00:23:55.778 --> 00:23:56.348
There it is.

449
00:23:56.348 --> 00:23:57.696
I was like where are the colors here.

450
00:23:57.696 --> 00:24:01.370
It's View and then Coloring Rules,
that's what I was looking for.

451
00:24:02.420 --> 00:24:05.410
And it's in here that
I may find something.

452
00:24:05.410 --> 00:24:09.010
And this is kind of nice because it
shows you what the default colors are.

453
00:24:09.010 --> 00:24:12.100
Let's say that I don't like
this checksum error being this

454
00:24:12.100 --> 00:24:13.690
kind of black with red background.

455
00:24:13.690 --> 00:24:15.470
I don't have to actually turn that on.

456
00:24:15.470 --> 00:24:17.720
I can just take that off if I wanted to.

457
00:24:19.950 --> 00:24:21.440
And notice you can also export and

458
00:24:21.440 --> 00:24:25.000
import these into another
setting if you want to as well.

459
00:24:25.000 --> 00:24:28.440
You can even create your own here-
>> That looks like a good opportunity for

460
00:24:28.440 --> 00:24:31.940
a screenshot if you're studying 'till
like you memorize the different colors.

461
00:24:31.940 --> 00:24:34.980
>> Yeah, that's actually something
good to think about here.

462
00:24:34.980 --> 00:24:38.970
So you can do that, and of course
if you wanted to you can now create

463
00:24:38.970 --> 00:24:42.520
some different filters that you can apply.

464
00:24:42.520 --> 00:24:46.210
But you name it, just changing something
like that can be fairly helpful.

465
00:24:46.210 --> 00:24:49.930
Let's see if I can do something that will
actually show up a little bit easier here.

466
00:24:49.930 --> 00:24:52.440
As I try to just do something, let's see.

467
00:24:52.440 --> 00:24:54.200
Bad TCP, let's do that one too.

468
00:24:54.200 --> 00:24:58.180
And then we'll take ARP, and
we'll just decolorize that.

469
00:24:59.290 --> 00:25:00.480
And click OK.

470
00:25:00.480 --> 00:25:04.110
Now notice that we did, it actually took
away like the art color you see where it's

471
00:25:04.110 --> 00:25:08.910
kind of grayed out up here and
stopping and you know, all that stuff.

472
00:25:08.910 --> 00:25:13.140
Well, now that's what's happening
is your profile is now set.

473
00:25:13.140 --> 00:25:15.580
You don't have to worry about saving it or
anything else.

474
00:25:15.580 --> 00:25:18.430
But if I switch profiles from this point.

475
00:25:18.430 --> 00:25:19.670
Somebody else is using the machine.

476
00:25:19.670 --> 00:25:22.700
Notice it goes back to
the default profile again.

477
00:25:22.700 --> 00:25:26.250
And now if ARP actually continues on,
it should kind of show up and

478
00:25:26.250 --> 00:25:29.780
do some of the other things that
you see right there and available.

479
00:25:29.780 --> 00:25:31.070
So it's just that simple.

480
00:25:31.070 --> 00:25:34.290
We don't have to worry then about,
did I leave it unchanged?

481
00:25:34.290 --> 00:25:37.408
Did I not Changing those profiles-
>> Ronnie's gonna kill me.

482
00:25:37.408 --> 00:25:38.960
[LAUGH]
>> While you switch it very easily, yeah,

483
00:25:38.960 --> 00:25:39.640
very quickly.

484
00:25:39.640 --> 00:25:42.920
Hopefully not, but overall though,
you can understand if you're

485
00:25:42.920 --> 00:25:46.410
using somebody else's machine and go,
I don't like the way that they do that.

486
00:25:46.410 --> 00:25:50.090
Well, create a profile, and
then change it if you want to, and

487
00:25:50.090 --> 00:25:53.510
switch it back when everything
is actually ready to go, right?

488
00:25:53.510 --> 00:25:55.500
So, that's all you have to do.

489
00:25:55.500 --> 00:25:58.550
And switch everything back,
select ITProTV, and there you go.

490
00:25:58.550 --> 00:26:03.000
Notice didn't have to go back through and
change the font size, remove colors,

491
00:26:03.000 --> 00:26:06.100
add colors in,
you do this on your own profile, and

492
00:26:06.100 --> 00:26:10.640
now you can show it in a little bit
better light, add in your own filters and

493
00:26:10.640 --> 00:26:12.075
then you know that you can do things.

494
00:26:12.075 --> 00:26:13.070
So this is very good,

495
00:26:13.070 --> 00:26:17.430
especially when you realize that, when
you start truly needing to capture data.

496
00:26:17.430 --> 00:26:19.950
Some of the things you really need
to filter out is your own data.

497
00:26:19.950 --> 00:26:22.420
Because you don't really care
about seeing that so much.

498
00:26:22.420 --> 00:26:25.660
You need to make sure that you're actually
seeing the data that you want to see.

499
00:26:25.660 --> 00:26:28.130
So it is open and available to you.

500
00:26:28.130 --> 00:26:32.560
Being able to understand what you
see inside of the layout itself,

501
00:26:32.560 --> 00:26:35.470
as far as the interface goes,
is kind of key.

502
00:26:35.470 --> 00:26:39.090
And then, of course, being able to create
profiles to match what you need to do

503
00:26:39.090 --> 00:26:41.740
is also going to help you to
become much more effective.

504
00:26:41.740 --> 00:26:46.030
And then you're going where did I remember
to change that or did I not change it?

505
00:26:46.030 --> 00:26:49.280
You can do a lot of different things
that will really help you to get

506
00:26:49.280 --> 00:26:50.560
faster and better.

507
00:26:50.560 --> 00:26:53.850
But now you have at least
a couple of different tools

508
00:26:53.850 --> 00:26:56.030
to be able to use Wireshark, right?

509
00:26:56.030 --> 00:26:59.668
You now know how to do a basic
kind of of a packet capture, okay,

510
00:26:59.668 --> 00:27:04.427
where you just saying hey, this is how big
it's gonna go up continue let mine run.

511
00:27:04.427 --> 00:27:09.087
We're now up to 2,500 different packets,
or a little bit under 2,600

512
00:27:09.087 --> 00:27:13.471
packets that's fine, but you now can
also create different profiles, you

513
00:27:13.471 --> 00:27:18.334
can manipulate the interface that you see,
and that's just gonna help you to make it

514
00:27:18.334 --> 00:27:22.978
feel more customized and more comfortable
with what you want to do as well okay.

515
00:27:22.978 --> 00:27:26.730
So that's actually a pretty good rounded
portion there of some of the things that

516
00:27:26.730 --> 00:27:31.870
we need to do but we still have a gigantic
haystack that we have to get through and

517
00:27:31.870 --> 00:27:35.000
we're not there though we're rushing
finding exactly what we need but

518
00:27:35.000 --> 00:27:37.520
we'll tackle that in
an upcoming episode as well.

519
00:27:37.520 --> 00:27:41.020
>> Yeah, we do have a lot of information
to cover, but at least we got started with

520
00:27:41.020 --> 00:27:44.330
the inner workings of using that interface
so thank you for coming in today.

521
00:27:44.330 --> 00:27:46.760
And thank you ladies and
gentlemen for tuning in.

522
00:27:46.760 --> 00:27:50.170
But stay tuned, we're gonna be looking
at some filters coming up next.

523
00:27:50.170 --> 00:27:53.220
So we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this show.

524
00:27:53.220 --> 00:27:55.210
Remember, I'm your show host,
Cherokee Boose.

525
00:27:55.210 --> 00:27:55.950
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

526
00:27:55.950 --> 00:27:58.663
>> See you next time, here at ITProTV.

527
00:27:58.663 --> 00:28:04.615
[MUSIC]

528
00:28:04.615 --> 00:28:08.182
Thank you for watching ItPro TV

episodes.description: Packet capturing can be overwhelming. Ronnie and Cherokee explain how to find the proverbial needle in the haystack. Ronnie explains and demonstrates the differences of capture versus display filters.
episodes.title: Use Filters
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:03.585
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm you host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.585 --> 00:00:08.332
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:08.332 --> 00:00:14.080
>> Welcome to your Wireshark's Theories.

4
00:00:14.080 --> 00:00:16.510
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:16.510 --> 00:00:18.850
In this episode we'll
be looking at filters.

6
00:00:18.850 --> 00:00:22.080
We've all ready briefly mentioned
different types of filters such as capture

7
00:00:22.080 --> 00:00:23.510
and display filters.

8
00:00:23.510 --> 00:00:26.000
But with us today in studios, we have Mr.

9
00:00:26.000 --> 00:00:28.960
Ronnie Wong to really dive deep and
explain the difference.

10
00:00:28.960 --> 00:00:30.500
And how we can examine these filters.

11
00:00:30.500 --> 00:00:32.220
Thank you or joining us today, Ronnie.

12
00:00:32.220 --> 00:00:35.300
>> Thank you for having me back
as we continue on now to and

13
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:38.780
do what we really want Wireshark to do,
right?

14
00:00:38.780 --> 00:00:40.900
Capturing all the packets.

15
00:00:40.900 --> 00:00:42.910
Being able to see everything.

16
00:00:42.910 --> 00:00:45.720
It can be overwhelming, and
that's kind of the key, right.

17
00:00:45.720 --> 00:00:49.100
So regular packets sniffing,
that's where everything begins.

18
00:00:49.100 --> 00:00:51.470
We have to be able to see
everything that we wanna see.

19
00:00:51.470 --> 00:00:55.520
But at the same time,
it shows us not only that but more.

20
00:00:55.520 --> 00:00:58.050
So it's not that the data isn't in there,
it's just so

21
00:00:58.050 --> 00:01:00.480
much data, more than you actually have.

22
00:01:00.480 --> 00:01:02.340
And more than you really want to see.

23
00:01:02.340 --> 00:01:05.960
And this is the reason why we actually
have to use something like what we call

24
00:01:05.960 --> 00:01:07.980
different filters to help us out.

25
00:01:07.980 --> 00:01:09.090
Currently for us,

26
00:01:09.090 --> 00:01:13.420
if we were to take the idea of just
doing a packet capturing over time.

27
00:01:13.420 --> 00:01:16.380
It can flood our particular
network adapter so

28
00:01:16.380 --> 00:01:20.330
much so
that it's just too much to look at.

29
00:01:20.330 --> 00:01:24.150
So what we're looking for, of course, then
is that proverbial needle in a hay stack.

30
00:01:24.150 --> 00:01:28.800
And the way that we find it, right,
is by using different types of filters

31
00:01:28.800 --> 00:01:32.430
that are available to
us inside of Wireshark.

32
00:01:32.430 --> 00:01:37.380
Now before we do that, right, you need to
understand that there's some impact on

33
00:01:37.380 --> 00:01:42.010
using a certain type of filter rather
than another type of filter, as well.

34
00:01:42.010 --> 00:01:46.980
So let's talk about the two concepts here,
Cherokee, for just a moment, as well.

35
00:01:46.980 --> 00:01:50.677
>> Sure, I'm really curious to see why
one would choose one type of filter

36
00:01:50.677 --> 00:01:51.547
over the other.

37
00:01:51.547 --> 00:01:52.058
What are we looking at?

38
00:01:52.058 --> 00:01:54.749
>> When you start to take a look
at that idea of the filters,

39
00:01:54.749 --> 00:01:58.580
there's really two basic types of
filters that we use in Wireshark.

40
00:01:58.580 --> 00:02:01.146
One of course is what's called
a capture filter, okay.

41
00:02:01.146 --> 00:02:05.540
And then the other one is what
we call a display filter.

42
00:02:05.540 --> 00:02:09.130
Now the great thing is
the name really gives it away

43
00:02:09.130 --> 00:02:12.790
about when a filtering happens, okay.

44
00:02:12.790 --> 00:02:17.050
When do we start filtering the data
to show what we want it to show

45
00:02:17.050 --> 00:02:18.460
when it happens?

46
00:02:18.460 --> 00:02:22.600
So when we start to think and
we start to talk about it,

47
00:02:22.600 --> 00:02:25.980
it's very easy to get confused
if you don't understand that.

48
00:02:25.980 --> 00:02:29.754
So capture filter,
hopefully the name makes sense here,

49
00:02:29.754 --> 00:02:33.520
is that it happens when
the capture takes place.

50
00:02:33.520 --> 00:02:36.159
Now when we start using capture filters,

51
00:02:37.200 --> 00:02:42.220

503
00:26:40.510 --> 00:26:43.760
as well as display filters
are really going to show us,

504
00:26:43.760 --> 00:26:47.710
or at least get us in that ballpark,
of what we're starting to take a look at.

505
00:26:47.710 --> 00:26:50.930
Now, sometimes you can also
filter in a different way too.

506
00:26:50.930 --> 00:26:53.830
So, let me show you one last option here,
okay?

507
00:26:53.830 --> 00:26:57.838
So, I've just taken away the entire
display from this point.

508
00:26:57.838 --> 00:27:00.231
I can right click.

509
00:27:00.231 --> 00:27:02.087
And if I now show you the menu,

510
00:27:02.087 --> 00:27:06.810
notice that there are some other
options as far as the filter goes.

511
00:27:06.810 --> 00:27:10.260
Notice I can select this where
it says Apply as a Filter.

512
00:27:10.260 --> 00:27:12.960
Selected, Not Selected, and, or.

513
00:27:12.960 --> 00:27:15.650
Or I can prepare it as a filter as well.

514
00:27:15.650 --> 00:27:18.612
So, this one we can see
just a little bit more.

515
00:27:18.612 --> 00:27:22.844
You can even take a look at a conversation
filter, depending on what we're looking

516
00:27:22.844 --> 00:27:28.140
at, whether Ethernet, in other words layer
two or layer three information, or to UDP.

517
00:27:28.140 --> 00:27:31.430
So, there are multiple ways
we can create filters, not

518
00:27:31.430 --> 00:27:35.880
necessarily all about learning the syntax
but you do have that ability to do so.

519
00:27:35.880 --> 00:27:39.640
And this one is just a display filter.

520
00:27:39.640 --> 00:27:42.750
I was trying to remember what it was but
yeah, it's just a display filter.

521
00:27:42.750 --> 00:27:44.850
It's not a capture filter at this point.

522
00:27:44.850 --> 00:27:46.820
So, you'll still be able to see that,

523
00:27:46.820 --> 00:27:51.300
and then it will paste it right here
in the bar just like what we did here.

524
00:27:51.300 --> 00:27:53.285
And once we have that up and available,

525
00:27:53.285 --> 00:27:57.850
it will give us essentially what we need
to help eliminate that a little bit more.

526
00:27:57.850 --> 00:28:01.532
So, you may not remember everybody's IP
address like what we were doing here, but

527
00:28:01.532 --> 00:28:04.732
you may be able to spot the one
that you have as it goes across.

528
00:28:04.732 --> 00:28:06.125
Let me filter by this one.

529
00:28:06.125 --> 00:28:08.661
Simply right click on it, select and
go filter or eliminate it.

530
00:28:08.661 --> 00:28:09.683
>> Nice.

531
00:28:09.683 --> 00:28:11.604
>> And you'll be able to do that.
>> Just eliminating a couple steps.

532
00:28:11.604 --> 00:28:12.620
>> It really does.

533
00:28:12.620 --> 00:28:15.722
So, those are kind of some of the
different options that you have available.

534
00:28:15.722 --> 00:28:21.840
Now, did we really even scratch
the surface of how in depth this can go?

535
00:28:21.840 --> 00:28:22.740
Not really.

536
00:28:22.740 --> 00:28:26.160
This is really just to get you prepared
to be able to do some of this.

537
00:28:26.160 --> 00:28:30.545
And we may do a little bit more on this in
a couple of later episodes as we develop

538
00:28:30.545 --> 00:28:32.176
this show as it comes along.

539
00:28:32.176 --> 00:28:32.715
>> Sounds good.
>> But

540
00:28:32.715 --> 00:28:37.150
overall though at least we'll get
you started in understanding that.

541
00:28:37.150 --> 00:28:39.970
Getting the information to
your machine is one thing.

542
00:28:39.970 --> 00:28:44.317
Starting to make it show only what you
want it to show is really when you start

543
00:28:44.317 --> 00:28:47.563
to use the power of Wireshark
that's available to you.

544
00:28:47.563 --> 00:28:49.232
And that's what we want to get to.

545
00:28:49.232 --> 00:28:50.027
>> And I think we will.

546
00:28:50.027 --> 00:28:52.215
We do have a lot more to cover,
so stay tuned.

547
00:28:52.215 --> 00:28:56.670
We're gonna be capturing more data in
the next series, or show I should say.

548
00:28:56.670 --> 00:28:58.467
But thank you so much for
tuning into today.

549
00:28:58.467 --> 00:29:01.633
But we're gonna go ahead and sign off for
this show, my name is Cherokee Boose.

550
00:29:01.633 --> 00:29:02.494
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

551
00:29:02.494 --> 00:29:05.568
>> See you next time here at ITPro TV

552
00:29:05.568 --> 00:29:11.478
[MUSIC]

553
00:29:11.478 --> 00:29:14.829
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Knowing where to logically place your sniffing tool depends on what type of data you are trying to collect or what type of problem you are trying. Ronnie explains methods such  to capture individual conversations or unicast transmissions.
episodes.title: Capture Unicast Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.793
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:03.793 --> 00:00:08.218
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.218 --> 00:00:11.836
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.836 --> 00:00:16.160
>> Welcome to your Wireshark series,
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:16.160 --> 00:00:21.179
In this episode, we will be looking at how
to really just identify Unicast traffic.

6
00:00:21.179 --> 00:00:24.064
With us today, we have Mr.
Ronnie Wong in studios.

7
00:00:24.064 --> 00:00:25.840
Thank you for joining us today, Ronnie.

8
00:00:25.840 --> 00:00:28.932
>> Well, thank you for having me back
as we continue on taking a look at

9
00:00:28.932 --> 00:00:33.019
using Wireshark, of course, to help us see
some more details about our network using,

10
00:00:33.019 --> 00:00:36.150
of course,
the packets that go across the interface.

11
00:00:36.150 --> 00:00:39.870
Now, when we started off right, and
we talked about the idea capturing all

12
00:00:39.870 --> 00:00:44.820
the packets that come in on the interface,
well, we expect to see some traffic,

13
00:00:44.820 --> 00:00:49.190
but what we're normally looking for,
though, is what we call a conversation.

14
00:00:49.190 --> 00:00:53.840
And usually, the problem that we have is
the conversation is not between my machine

15
00:00:53.840 --> 00:00:58.660
and the problem machine nor between
the problem machine and my machine.

16
00:00:58.660 --> 00:01:03.990
It normally is between the problem machine
and, of course, or another machine, okay?

17
00:01:03.990 --> 00:01:07.130
So at one point in time,
in terms of networking,

18
00:01:07.130 --> 00:01:10.600
it was fairly simple to be able
to capture data like that.

19
00:01:10.600 --> 00:01:16.370
And that was because 20, 30 years ago, we
were all using hubs inside of our network.

20
00:01:16.370 --> 00:01:18.070
Now, 30 years ago,
I might be a little bit far,

21
00:01:18.070 --> 00:01:22.620
but we were all essentially
using a hub to connect in.

22
00:01:22.620 --> 00:01:26.265
Now, remember that what a hub is just
a simple connectivity device, and

23
00:01:26.265 --> 00:01:28.160
everybody plugs into it.

24
00:01:28.160 --> 00:01:32.210
So if Cherokee and
I were plugged into a hub, and you were

25
00:01:32.210 --> 00:01:36.880
also plugged into the same hub, even if
Cherokee was sending data directly to me,

26
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.550
essentially, you or Nick would also get
a copy of that traffic as well, okay?

27
00:01:42.550 --> 00:01:45.150
That's because that's
the way that hubs function.

28
00:01:45.150 --> 00:01:49.770
So it might be that your particular NIC
would get a copy of that data, that was

29
00:01:49.770 --> 00:01:54.530
really only between Cherokee's machine and
mine, but you'd still get a copy of it.

30
00:01:54.530 --> 00:01:56.100
Now, most of the time,

31
00:01:56.100 --> 00:01:59.510
the NICs were fairly easy in
the way that they did things.

32
00:01:59.510 --> 00:02:01.400
They'd go, okay, it doesn't belong to me.

33
00:02:01.400 --> 00:02:05.430
If I'm not the destination, I'll just
drop the packet, no big deal, okay?

34
00:02:05.430 --> 00:02:08.454
So that's pretty much
what we expect to see.

35
00:02:08.454 --> 00:02:13.163
Now, the problem that we have, though,
is in today's switch networks,

36
00:02:13.163 --> 00:02:16.323
we can't even get a hint of that anymore,
right?

37
00:02:16.323 --> 00:02:19.828
So Cherokee, when we start talking
about the hub and a switch,

38
00:02:19.828 --> 00:02:24.740
a switch's differentiation is a little bit
harsher, because a switch only does what?

39
00:02:24.740 --> 00:02:26.880
It really only connects
two ports together, right?

40
00:02:26.880 --> 00:02:32.260
>> Yeah, that's gonna be, hold on
a second, our contingent domain there.

41
00:02:32.260 --> 00:02:36.070
We've really eliminated that, and
we've created our individual zones.

42
00:02:36.070 --> 00:02:38.770
>> Yeah, when it comes down
to it each port, essentially,

43
00:02:38.770 --> 00:02:41.980
only directly connects to
another port on the switch.

44
00:02:41.980 --> 00:02:45.756
So I have a five-port switch, or
a six-port switch, eight-port switch.

45
00:02:45.756 --> 00:02:48.990
If I'm sending from port number
one to port number eight,

46
00:02:48.990 --> 00:02:52.590
the port number two through seven,
they don't even see the traffic.

47
00:02:52.590 --> 00:02:57.020
So, me just taking my computer
with Wireshark on it, and

48
00:02:57.020 --> 00:03:01.000
plugging into port number five, doesn't
mean I can capture the traffic between

49
00:03:01.000 --> 00:03:03.820
port number one and
port number eight, okay?

50
00:03:03.820 --> 00:03:08.842
So that's where we have some problems
in terms of using Wireshark to

51
00:03:08.842 --> 00:03:14.141
capture what data between what we
think that we need to capture, okay?

52
00:03:14.141 --> 00:03:18.977
So let's make sure that we understand what
types of data we are normally going to

53
00:03:18.977 --> 00:03:23.173
end up seeing when we plug Wireshark
into a switched network, okay?

54
00:03:23.173 --> 00:03:24.385
So let's take a look at my machine.

55
00:03:24.385 --> 00:03:27.975
I just wrote down four different words
here to make sure that I remembered what

56
00:03:27.975 --> 00:03:30.180
they were more than anything else here.

57
00:03:30.180 --> 00:03:33.200
There's four possible types
of traffic that you and

58
00:03:33.200 --> 00:03:37.400
I will see if we take our machine, and
we plug Wireshark directly into it.

59
00:03:37.400 --> 00:03:40.540
The first and foremost is broadcast, okay?

60
00:03:40.540 --> 00:03:46.120
Well, broadcast is when you take a look
at the way that a switch functions.

61
00:03:46.120 --> 00:03:51.200
When a switch receives a broadcast
into the switch from a single port,

62
00:03:51.200 --> 00:03:55.830
it automatically floods it out every other
port, except for the one it came in on.

63
00:03:55.830 --> 00:03:58.080
That's just the way
it's designed to do it.

64
00:03:58.080 --> 00:03:59.550
So it knows how to do that, and

65
00:03:59.550 --> 00:04:04.900
it sends it out to a broadcast type
of MAC address, is what it does.

66
00:04:04.900 --> 00:04:08.141
So usually, you might end up seeing where,

67
00:04:08.141 --> 00:04:13.230
let me see if I can do this here,
the MAC address turns out to be all Fs.

68
00:04:15.137 --> 00:04:17.579
Oops, let me do one more.

69
00:04:17.579 --> 00:04:22.600
It doesn't look as [LAUGH]
bold as I expected it to look.

70
00:04:22.600 --> 00:04:23.660
I don't know why.

71
00:04:23.660 --> 00:04:24.830
There we go, a little bit better.

72
00:04:24.830 --> 00:04:26.240
>> Yeah.

73
00:04:26.240 --> 00:04:29.633
>> Okay, so normally, it turns out
to actually look like all Fs here.

74
00:04:29.633 --> 00:04:32.885
Now, you might see it actually written
in two, and then with dashes or

75
00:04:32.885 --> 00:04:35.048
dots in between,
whether it might be colons.

76
00:04:35.048 --> 00:04:36.450
>> Yeah, colons.

77
00:04:36.450 --> 00:04:37.450
>> So you might have that,

78
00:04:37.450 --> 00:04:40.800
but this is normally where you will
see the destination Mac address.

79
00:04:40.800 --> 00:04:42.470
It will be there, okay?

80
00:04:42.470 --> 00:04:45.664
But in a Multicast, though, okay?

81
00:04:45.664 --> 00:04:47.401
A Multicast traffic is
designed to do this.

82
00:04:47.401 --> 00:04:51.220
Let's take that eight-port switch for
an example, right?

83
00:04:51.220 --> 00:04:53.640
>> Sure.
>> If Cherokee's machine sends out

84
00:04:53.640 --> 00:04:58.334
a Multicast, it might only began to
push number two, four and six, okay?

85
00:04:58.334 --> 00:05:00.120
>> Only members of that Multicast group?

86
00:05:00.120 --> 00:05:02.470
>> Yeah,
only members of that Multicast group.

87
00:05:02.470 --> 00:05:04.630
All right, Cherokee,
go ahead, all right, cool.

88
00:05:04.630 --> 00:05:06.840
So when we have something like that,

89
00:05:06.840 --> 00:05:10.790
it doesn't disturb every single
port on that switch, but

90
00:05:10.790 --> 00:05:15.120
we might be part of that Multicast
group where we also get that traffic.

91
00:05:15.120 --> 00:05:19.190
And if we do that, that normally
means that that particular Multicast,

92
00:05:19.190 --> 00:05:24.260
it has a destination MAC address
usually of something like this.

93
00:05:24.260 --> 00:05:27.460
And this is what we were talking
about in the earlier episode here

94
00:05:29.270 --> 00:05:32.240
where it's 5E, oops, I can't, E.

95
00:05:32.240 --> 00:05:34.087
And then it's anything else that follows.

96
00:05:38.280 --> 00:05:43.090
So normally for us,
it goes from 5E01, or actually 00,

97
00:05:43.090 --> 00:05:48.800
all the way through 5E, and
then all Fs, here is what it can go to.

98
00:05:48.800 --> 00:05:50.510
So that's a Multicast address.

99
00:05:50.510 --> 00:05:54.378
And so I tricked Cherokee last time
when we did the display filter or

100
00:05:54.378 --> 00:05:59.025
capture filter and say, hey, does that
MAC address look a little bit strange?

101
00:05:59.025 --> 00:06:02.430
Well, it's the ending of the 5E
that always gives it away for me.

102
00:06:02.430 --> 00:06:03.654
>> The broadcast is easy to remember.

103
00:06:03.654 --> 00:06:04.385
>> Yeah, broadcast is easy.

104
00:06:04.385 --> 00:06:05.262
>> Why didn't you ask me about that one?

105
00:06:05.262 --> 00:06:07.900
>> Yeah, this one is so much, okay?

106
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:11.344
Now, the other one is a little
bit harder to identify, and

107
00:06:11.344 --> 00:06:14.521
that is because of what we
call is an Unknown Unicast.

108
00:06:14.521 --> 00:06:18.128
Now Cherokee, have you ever heard
of an Unknown Unicast for this?

109
00:06:18.128 --> 00:06:21.940
>> Unknown Unicast, no, I don't know.

110
00:06:21.940 --> 00:06:25.858
>> Yeah, it's not that it's uncommon,
but most of us don't know about this,

111
00:06:25.858 --> 00:06:28.591
because we don't think about
it in this term, okay?

112
00:06:28.591 --> 00:06:30.798
But think about a couple things
that can happen on a switch, right?

113
00:06:30.798 --> 00:06:31.462
>> Okay.

114
00:06:31.462 --> 00:06:34.060
>> I know that if I
wanted to send data from

115
00:06:34.060 --> 00:06:38.600
my machine over to Cherokee's machine,
the switch says what?

116
00:06:38.600 --> 00:06:40.330
>> Okay, wait.
I have an idea.

117
00:06:40.330 --> 00:06:41.088
>> What?
>> I could be totally wrong here.

118
00:06:41.088 --> 00:06:42.670
>> Okay.

119
00:06:42.670 --> 00:06:45.790
>> If it doesn't have that MAC
address already in the cam table or

120
00:06:45.790 --> 00:06:47.760
that memory table in the switch.

121
00:06:47.760 --> 00:06:49.010
>> That is correct.

122
00:06:49.010 --> 00:06:50.342
So remember-
>> I remember when Cisco,

123
00:06:50.342 --> 00:06:51.406
a little bit about that now,
okay, all right.

124
00:06:51.406 --> 00:06:52.838
>> Yeah, there you go, see.

125
00:06:52.838 --> 00:06:55.970
>> Yeah, that's where we
normally hear about it is Cisco.

126
00:06:55.970 --> 00:06:59.180
So that's why I said we're not trying to
impress you with Cisco knowledge, but

127
00:06:59.180 --> 00:07:01.240
I didn't wanna bring in
more than we have to.

128
00:07:01.240 --> 00:07:04.140
So we just talk about the idea
of an Unknown Unicast.

129
00:07:04.140 --> 00:07:09.303
It is possible that Cherokee's machine
sends something out to a MAC address

130
00:07:09.303 --> 00:07:13.914
that's not already inside of the MAC
address table on that switch.

131
00:07:13.914 --> 00:07:15.490
Very possible, okay?

132
00:07:15.490 --> 00:07:17.819
Now, the switch still has to
make a decision with that, and

133
00:07:17.819 --> 00:07:20.100
it's only got three decisions it can make.

134
00:07:20.100 --> 00:07:23.230
Forward the data to whatever
other port it wants to go to,

135
00:07:23.230 --> 00:07:26.390
flood the data out every other port,
or drop it.

136
00:07:26.390 --> 00:07:29.010
And that's pretty much
all that it has there.

137
00:07:29.010 --> 00:07:33.930
An Unknown Unicast says it's
not in my MAC address table but

138
00:07:33.930 --> 00:07:35.430
the way that the switch works.

139
00:07:35.430 --> 00:07:39.910
Or I like to give it human
characteristics here.

140
00:07:39.910 --> 00:07:41.770
The way that a switch works is it goes,

141
00:07:41.770 --> 00:07:44.890
look, I don't see it in
my MAC address table.

142
00:07:44.890 --> 00:07:49.170
But overall, though,
Cherokee is sending it there,

143
00:07:49.170 --> 00:07:52.190
which means she might know
something that I don't.

144
00:07:52.190 --> 00:07:54.507
And it plugged in,
it's just not responding now.

145
00:07:54.507 --> 00:07:59.744
So all I have to do is get that
particular device to respond.

146
00:07:59.744 --> 00:08:03.140
The easiest way to do this is
to flood out every other port.

147
00:08:03.140 --> 00:08:07.090
And then maybe it will actually
return a response to that as well.

148
00:08:07.090 --> 00:08:10.618
>> Okay, Ronnie,
if the switch is able to find that device,

149
00:08:10.618 --> 00:08:14.221
will it then add the information
to its memory table there?

150
00:08:14.221 --> 00:08:15.580
>> Yeah, it really will.

151
00:08:15.580 --> 00:08:18.490
So because of the way that
the switch does think that

152
00:08:18.490 --> 00:08:21.730
Cherokee's computer knows more
the network than it does.

153
00:08:21.730 --> 00:08:25.410
It just assumes that when it
does that flooding out everyone

154
00:08:25.410 --> 00:08:29.070
that somewhere along the line it's gonna
get the response of that MAC address.

155
00:08:29.070 --> 00:08:31.020
And if it's out there,
it will go ahead and

156
00:08:31.020 --> 00:08:34.875
add that back into the MAC address table.

157
00:08:34.875 --> 00:08:36.515
And if it does that
then everything's good,

158
00:08:36.515 --> 00:08:40.315
from that point on it will be unicast
traffic and we're ready to go, okay.

159
00:08:40.315 --> 00:08:44.705
So it can do that, but if it's not there,
it will just continue to try and

160
00:08:44.705 --> 00:08:49.845
flood it out every port until your
machine says, I'm gonna stop sending.

161
00:08:49.845 --> 00:08:56.365
And ultimately though, if I am plugged
then to that 8-port switch with my machine

162
00:08:56.365 --> 00:09:00.444
and I'm running Wireshark, The only other
thing that I should get is a Unicast,

163
00:09:00.444 --> 00:09:01.988
okay now that makes sense, right?

164
00:09:01.988 --> 00:09:03.516
>> Yes.
>> Unicast is directly from one

165
00:09:03.516 --> 00:09:06.910
Mac address to another Mac address and
that's what we have here.

166
00:09:06.910 --> 00:09:10.210
>> So this is just a specific Mac address,
now this one's not so

167
00:09:10.210 --> 00:09:12.425
much to find as much

168
00:09:12.425 --> 00:09:13.380
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Yep.

169
00:09:13.380 --> 00:09:20.196
So this is just a unique Mac address,
if I can spell unique MAC address.

170
00:09:20.196 --> 00:09:26.380
[LAUGH] All right, now this is important.

171
00:09:26.380 --> 00:09:30.180

00:22:21.200 --> 00:22:23.050
So, I have a 48 port switch here.

393
00:22:23.050 --> 00:22:25.850
I could take all the other 47 ports,
and say what?

394
00:22:25.850 --> 00:22:28.420
Going to mirror that
traffic to this one port.

395
00:22:28.420 --> 00:22:29.990
>> Wow.
>> Then you'll over subscribe that port

396
00:22:29.990 --> 00:22:30.535
like crazy.

397
00:22:30.535 --> 00:22:31.490
>> [LAUGH] Wow.

398
00:22:31.490 --> 00:22:35.740
>> So yeah, if you think that, and
this is not the fanciest switching, right?

399
00:22:35.740 --> 00:22:38.552
These are fast Ethernet ports,
but that's 47 100 megabit ports.

400
00:22:38.552 --> 00:22:40.989
>> Still,
when you think of it exponentially, and

401
00:22:40.989 --> 00:22:44.503
that manner it's gonna be pretty
taxing on that one particular port.

402
00:22:44.503 --> 00:22:48.670
>> Yeah, 47 100 megabit ports, if
they're all working very quickly, right?

403
00:22:48.670 --> 00:22:54.047
That one port's only 100 megabits and
I mean, that's 4,700 megabits,

404
00:22:54.047 --> 00:22:59.600
4.7 gigs, you're trying to cram into
that tiny little pipe that you have.

405
00:22:59.600 --> 00:23:01.830
It's not gonna all fit very easily.

406
00:23:01.830 --> 00:23:04.540
So you have that option, but will it work?

407
00:23:04.540 --> 00:23:08.290
Yes, here on my network where I can
capture just a little bit of the data.

408
00:23:08.290 --> 00:23:10.260
You see it working right here, too.

409
00:23:11.310 --> 00:23:13.920
Ideally though,
if you had the money, okay,

410
00:23:13.920 --> 00:23:17.680
it would be of course a network tap,
that you would plug in place.

411
00:23:17.680 --> 00:23:19.860
And then you could capture all the data.

412
00:23:19.860 --> 00:23:23.120
And by doing that, it actually doesn't
interfere with any of the traffic.

413
00:23:23.120 --> 00:23:28.976
It doesn't cause your switch to have to
consume more CPU, or cause any problems.

414
00:23:28.976 --> 00:23:32.130
Because it essentially works as a pass
through and all you're doing is you're

415
00:23:32.130 --> 00:23:35.890
really seeing the data as it
flows through that little tap.

416
00:23:35.890 --> 00:23:37.880
So it's an extra device and

417
00:23:37.880 --> 00:23:40.390
you can actually find these
devices just about everywhere.

418
00:23:40.390 --> 00:23:44.340
They are expensive but overall though,
it gives you that ability to do so.

419
00:23:44.340 --> 00:23:48.304
So don't think that you don't
have the option to do this.

420
00:23:48.304 --> 00:23:51.271
So rather as a configuration,
or an extra device,

421
00:23:51.271 --> 00:23:55.273
if you need to capture unicast data
that is not destined just for you,

422
00:23:55.273 --> 00:23:58.654
those are at least some of
the methods that you can use, and

423
00:23:58.654 --> 00:24:03.550
that can get you started in Wireshark
to see the data that you want to see.

424
00:24:03.550 --> 00:24:06.040
Now from this point,
you can also add in filters,

425
00:24:06.040 --> 00:24:08.950
which we've also talked
about in a previous episode.

426
00:24:08.950 --> 00:24:13.350
To really limit and see exactly what
you want to see turns a protocol or

427
00:24:13.350 --> 00:24:15.510
maybe even a specific source or

428
00:24:15.510 --> 00:24:20.120
destination address you're going to, but
this is what will get you to that point.

429
00:24:20.120 --> 00:24:24.260
>> I know, and just looking at this from
even a security standpoint it really makes

430
00:24:24.260 --> 00:24:27.670
you thing about your physical security
because if someone were to gain

431
00:24:27.670 --> 00:24:30.910
access to your physical network, look at
all the information they could obtain.

432
00:24:30.910 --> 00:24:31.780
That's quite a bit there, so.

433
00:24:31.780 --> 00:24:33.130
>> It really is.

434
00:24:33.130 --> 00:24:34.082
>> Yep, there's no doubt.

435
00:24:34.082 --> 00:24:35.840
All right, do you have any
other final thoughts Ronnie,

436
00:24:35.840 --> 00:24:36.920
I think we're about out of time for

437
00:24:36.920 --> 00:24:39.430
this show but,
>> [LAUGHS] Well, just think about it

438
00:24:39.430 --> 00:24:43.850
right, sometimes it's not gonna show
you everything that you wanted to see.

439
00:24:43.850 --> 00:24:49.530
But, make sure that you have a solid
understanding right, of how switches work.

440
00:24:49.530 --> 00:24:53.950
Even a basic understanding of
how the router works as well.

441
00:24:53.950 --> 00:24:56.920
And of course even how your
NIC works just a little bit.

442
00:24:56.920 --> 00:25:00.050
That way you can just troubleshoot
why your connections aren't showing

443
00:25:00.050 --> 00:25:01.070
the way that you want to.

444
00:25:01.070 --> 00:25:02.220
>> All right.
>> Even before the show,

445
00:25:02.220 --> 00:25:05.890
I had a problem just with my NICs,
trying to get them to kinda play along and

446
00:25:05.890 --> 00:25:08.860
do everything that I wanted to do and
setting it up in lab.

447
00:25:08.860 --> 00:25:11.480
It does, it takes a little bit of
time to get everything set up.

448
00:25:11.480 --> 00:25:15.310
But once you kind of understand it,
it will become a rhythm for you.

449
00:25:15.310 --> 00:25:16.690
And then you'll be able to plug right in,
and

450
00:25:16.690 --> 00:25:20.693
you'll be working with Wireshark in no
time to show you the data that you need.

451
00:25:20.693 --> 00:25:23.500
>> [LAUGH] Well thank you so
much Ronnie, and thank you ladies and

452
00:25:23.500 --> 00:25:24.470
gentleman for turning in.

453
00:25:24.470 --> 00:25:25.170
But stay tuned.

454
00:25:25.170 --> 00:25:26.960
We have more Wireshark headed your way.

455
00:25:26.960 --> 00:25:30.590
I'm gonna go ahead and sign off for
this show, as your host, Cherokee Boose,

456
00:25:30.590 --> 00:25:31.390
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong,

457
00:25:31.390 --> 00:25:34.250
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

458
00:25:34.250 --> 00:25:40.167
[MUSIC]

459
00:25:40.167 --> 00:25:43.670
Thank you watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: After exploring several features Cherokee and Ronnie take you further down the rabbit hole. By examining the TCP of a captured packet one may visually see the conversation happening. First, you will analyze Telnet packets followed by the secure alternative of SSH communications.
episodes.title: Use Advanced Features
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.914
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.914 --> 00:00:10.837
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:10.837 --> 00:00:14.230
>> Welcome to your Wireshark series.

4
00:00:14.230 --> 00:00:16.330
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:16.330 --> 00:00:19.440
So far we've had a good introduction
in how to use this product.

6
00:00:19.440 --> 00:00:22.210
But this episode,
we're really gonna just dive in there and

7
00:00:22.210 --> 00:00:24.030
look at some advanced features.

8
00:00:24.030 --> 00:00:25.220
With us today we have Mr.

9
00:00:25.220 --> 00:00:27.960
Ronnie Wong to help us get
through these advanced features.

10
00:00:27.960 --> 00:00:30.060
So exactly what are we gonna
be looking at here, Ronnie?

11
00:00:30.060 --> 00:00:33.750
>> Well, when it comes down to
the idea of using Wireshark and

12
00:00:33.750 --> 00:00:35.350
getting ready to start, right?

13
00:00:35.350 --> 00:00:36.170
We've already showed a lot.

14
00:00:36.170 --> 00:00:38.870
And we've already showed you
how to at least install it,

15
00:00:38.870 --> 00:00:40.680
how to get started with making a capture,
and

16
00:00:40.680 --> 00:00:44.500
then of course filtering which is one of
the most important things that we can do.

17
00:00:44.500 --> 00:00:48.820
That's when we start to be able to
isolate down to that traffic that we

18
00:00:48.820 --> 00:00:52.040
really want to be able to capture,
and then use that of course for

19
00:00:52.040 --> 00:00:55.460
analysis into whatever
we need it to point out.

20
00:00:55.460 --> 00:00:57.120
But a lot of times though,

21
00:00:57.120 --> 00:01:01.110
what we also need is not just
the individual packets itself.

22
00:01:01.110 --> 00:01:04.360
Analyzing a particular packet works.

23
00:01:04.360 --> 00:01:09.260
It gives us what we might be able to break
down an individual component into, but

24
00:01:09.260 --> 00:01:11.660
it doesn't give us the entire picture.

25
00:01:11.660 --> 00:01:16.110
So we also need to understand
how Wireshark can also show us

26
00:01:16.110 --> 00:01:19.210
the idea of the entire picture, as well.

27
00:01:19.210 --> 00:01:23.200
So let's think about a conversation,
Cherokee, just at the beginning.

28
00:01:23.200 --> 00:01:28.380
If you were to call somebody up and
have a conversation, it begins with words,

29
00:01:28.380 --> 00:01:30.670
right, we use individual words.

30
00:01:30.670 --> 00:01:35.290
But if I were just to record individual
words and then record them and chop

31
00:01:35.290 --> 00:01:40.200
them up into one word at a time and then,
not assemble them in the proper manner.

32
00:01:40.200 --> 00:01:43.130
What you would end up getting is just,
well a bunch of words, right.

33
00:01:43.130 --> 00:01:45.000
And it doesn't make a lot of sense.

34
00:01:45.000 --> 00:01:47.870
>> Right, but Ronnie, don't we
normally follow some type of format or

35
00:01:47.870 --> 00:01:48.430
how does that go?

36
00:01:48.430 --> 00:01:50.170
What is that conversation made of?

37
00:01:50.170 --> 00:01:54.100
>> Yeah, when it comes down to just
a regular human conversation, right.

38
00:01:54.100 --> 00:01:58.640
Normally it kind of is done the same
way that a lot of times a computer

39
00:01:58.640 --> 00:01:59.620
does it as well.

40
00:01:59.620 --> 00:02:04.180
Now, let's go back to thinking a little
bit about the idea of the communication

41
00:02:04.180 --> 00:02:06.520
model that we think about here, okay?

42
00:02:06.520 --> 00:02:11.237
And the easiest one to think about of
course, is the idea of the TCP handshake.

43
00:02:11.237 --> 00:02:16.145
So the very beginning of that is just
about the idea here of sending the very

44
00:02:16.145 --> 00:02:18.780
fact that we want to communicate.

45
00:02:18.780 --> 00:02:20.300
So this is you picking up the phone and

46
00:02:20.300 --> 00:02:21.420
dialing someone,
>> Right.

47
00:02:21.420 --> 00:02:25.090
>> And then once they get that their
particular acknowledgment of that is when

48
00:02:25.090 --> 00:02:27.130
they pick up and they say hello.

49
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:30.820
And then, once they say that, you can kind
of know that you're on the same page.

50
00:02:30.820 --> 00:02:34.910
And from that point, you go hey, this is,
and let's say I'm on the other end, hey,

51
00:02:34.910 --> 00:02:35.550
this is Ronnie.

52
00:02:35.550 --> 00:02:39.300
>> For some reason, I always see Bob and
Sheila on diagrams online explaining TCP.

53
00:02:39.300 --> 00:02:40.360
I don't know why.

54
00:02:40.360 --> 00:02:41.290
Who's Bob and Sheila?

55
00:02:41.290 --> 00:02:41.815
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

56
00:02:41.815 --> 00:02:43.740
>> I'm pretty sure that they're out there.

57
00:02:43.740 --> 00:02:46.630
But the very fact is, since you and
I are on this I would use you and

58
00:02:46.630 --> 00:02:48.040
me as an example right.

59
00:02:48.040 --> 00:02:49.070
So here,

60
00:02:49.070 --> 00:02:52.690
that's where it begins, is that there
has to be some type of synchronization.

61
00:02:52.690 --> 00:02:55.490
But from that point,
it really is not just,

62
00:02:55.490 --> 00:02:58.120
now that we've made the connection
that that's all that there is.

63
00:02:58.120 --> 00:03:01.390
We now start to send data,
or we start to communicate.

64
00:03:01.390 --> 00:03:04.990
And it's the message that we
really want to be able to see,

65
00:03:04.990 --> 00:03:07.860
that entire what we call conversation.

66
00:03:07.860 --> 00:03:12.450
Well, computers chat as well, and that's
kind of the key that we want to get to

67
00:03:12.450 --> 00:03:16.800
when we start thinking about
the conversation between two computers.

68
00:03:16.800 --> 00:03:22.150
Can we use something like Wireshark
to help us to be able to do that?

69
00:03:22.150 --> 00:03:26.258
And it really does have to,
you really do, excuse me.

70
00:03:26.258 --> 00:03:30.080
You really as someone that is now
starting to examine traffic and

71
00:03:30.080 --> 00:03:32.360
starting to take look at it for analysis.

72
00:03:32.360 --> 00:03:36.790
You have to have those basic concepts
down for the explanation right.

73
00:03:36.790 --> 00:03:39.610
You need to understand
that the TCP handshake and

74
00:03:39.610 --> 00:03:44.270
what has to go on before computers
communicate because that is the beginning

75
00:03:44.270 --> 00:03:49.640
that connection that conversation and then
all those packets that flow afterwards,

76
00:03:49.640 --> 00:03:53.050
how do they know that that's all
connected to the same thing?

77
00:03:53.050 --> 00:03:55.080
Just like the conversation
between Cherokee and

78
00:03:55.080 --> 00:03:57.240
I on the telephone call, right?

79
00:03:57.240 --> 00:04:00.810
How is it that all of those are really
a part of that one conversation.

80
00:04:00.810 --> 00:04:04.080
Well when computers communicate we
have to understand that as well.

81
00:04:04.080 --> 00:04:06.460
And that is the idea what
we would call a flow or

82
00:04:06.460 --> 00:04:11.730
some type of course of stream of
traffic between those two systems.

83
00:04:11.730 --> 00:04:13.380
So we need to be able to understand and

84
00:04:13.380 --> 00:04:16.420
see that because even though like
I said at the very beginning

85
00:04:16.420 --> 00:04:20.020
that we can see individual packets and
break them down, right?

86
00:04:20.020 --> 00:04:23.400
We showed you in Wireshark where you can
actually see like an individual packet.

87
00:04:23.400 --> 00:04:26.604
You can break it down into all the layers
of the OSI model that Wireshark

88
00:04:26.604 --> 00:04:27.700
will show you.

89
00:04:27.700 --> 00:04:31.900
And even go down to see the hex values,
and the ASCII values,

90
00:04:31.900 --> 00:04:34.220
and essentially everything.

91
00:04:34.220 --> 00:04:37.600
But just looking at it packet by packet,
it's difficult.

92
00:04:37.600 --> 00:04:40.140
It's not actually easy to work.

93
00:04:40.140 --> 00:04:43.660
Now there are some
limitations in computers

94
00:04:43.660 --> 00:04:46.000
that we also have to think about.

95
00:04:46.000 --> 00:04:52.230
As humans, you and I can adjust, okay, to
the conversation and the message, right?

96
00:04:52.230 --> 00:04:55.735
There maybe sometimes just like Cherokee
did where she just gave me that verbal

97
00:04:55.735 --> 00:05:01.320
mm-hm which can be okay if I understand
like what I just said and she's

98
00:05:01.320 --> 00:05:04.560
agreeing with it but if she just said that
where I was in the middle of talking.

99
00:05:04.560 --> 00:05:09.340
I'm like what is she talking about, it
doesn't make any sense at that point but

100
00:05:09.340 --> 00:05:13.240
there may be times where,
what I say, she responds to.

101
00:05:13.240 --> 00:05:16.470
And then she just kind of
gives me a paragraph or

102
00:05:16.470 --> 00:05:21.190
two, or starts singing the middle of
a song, or whatever it might be, and

103
00:05:21.190 --> 00:05:25.320
I can adjust that because, as humans,
we can adjust the size and

104
00:05:25.320 --> 00:05:29.240
the nature of what we hear and realize
that that's a part of the conversation.

105
00:05:29.240 --> 00:05:32.540
Well remember that when we start
sending packets or frames back and

106
00:05:32.540 --> 00:05:35.320
forth between two computers,
there's normally a limitation.

107
00:05:35.320 --> 00:05:38.560
In other words, everything fits
into that particular limitation.

108
00:05:38.560 --> 00:05:40.890
So Cherokee,
what do you think ends up happening here.

109
00:05:40.890 --> 00:05:43.020
If I have something, so
let's just take the idea,

110
00:05:43.020 --> 00:05:47.110
about 1,500 bites,
a little bit larger or so.

111
00:05:47.110 --> 00:05:51.210
If it's 900 bytes of information,
that fits nicely in that container.

112
00:05:51.210 --> 00:05:51.990
That's fine.

113
00:05:51.990 --> 00:05:54.300
Send it over to you,
you get one packet, that's fine.

114
00:05:54.300 --> 00:05:59.760
But what if I have something like
4,200 bytes of information but

115
00:05:59.760 --> 00:06:02.430
my container is only 1,500 bytes?

116
00:06:02.430 --> 00:06:05.000
Well, now, what do we do with the rest of

117
00:06:05.000 --> 00:06:07.340
the conversation that we
were talking about having?

118
00:06:07.340 --> 00:06:11.780
With that computer,
what about those other 3,000 bites or so?

119
00:06:11.780 --> 00:06:13.840
What ends up happening there,
what do you think?

120
00:06:13.840 --> 00:06:17.950
>> Well, if our MTUs, our maximum
transmission units, are not able to handle

121
00:06:17.950 --> 00:06:21.680
large frames, like we spoke about
jumbo frames in previous shows, but

122
00:06:21.680 --> 00:06:23.000
that's a special environment.

123
00:06:24.260 --> 00:06:26.580
Regular equipment is limited, right?

124
00:06:26.580 --> 00:06:28.540
So we would need to fragment.

125
00:06:28.540 --> 00:06:30.140
>> Yeah, and that idea of fragment,

126
00:06:30.140 --> 00:06:34.430
that's kind of where it becomes
scary in the computer language land.

127
00:06:34.430 --> 00:06:40.220
In those particular pieces that we can't
fit in to that nice neat container size,

128
00:06:40.220 --> 00:06:45.070
well then it has to break off the pieces
it can't fit and put in its own container.

129
00:06:45.070 --> 00:06:47.050
And then whatever doesn't fit
in that one has to break off and

130
00:06:47.050 --> 00:06:49.000
put it into another container.

131
00:06:49.000 --> 00:06:52.570
Well now,
when we start sending that information,

132
00:06:52.570 --> 00:06:55.650
it no longer looks like a work,
let's say that for an example.

133
00:06:56.680 --> 00:06:58.923
This is kind of an unrealistic example but

134
00:06:58.923 --> 00:07:02.719
let's think about using just a regular
word let's just put ITProTV.

135
00:07:02.719 --> 00:07:06.590
And let's say that each one of those
is as big as each our frames can get.

136
00:07:06.590 --> 00:07:12.020
Well now, if I start to send that over to
Cherokee instead of her getting ITProTV,

137
00:07:12.020 --> 00:07:16.920
she actually gets an I in one of those
frames, a T in one of those frame, a P,

138
00:07:16.920 --> 00:07:21.140
an R, an O, and a T, and a T,
and another V in those frames.

139
00:07:21.140 --> 00:07:24.280
Well now that gets sent individually,
one at a time.

140
00:07:24.280 --> 00:07:28.935
So now, Cherokee,
does that actually represent ITProTV?

141
00:07:28.935 --> 00:07:32.520
Seven different words, or does that
represent seven different letters?

142
00:07:32.520 --> 00:07:35.960
Well how to computers know
the difference between those?

143
00:07:35.960 --> 00:07:36.880
>> Sequencing.

144
00:07:36.880 --> 00:07:40.800
>> Sequencing, but still at that time
right, it becomes a little bit harder for

145
00:07:40.800 --> 00:07:42.142
the computer to guess it.

146
00:07:42.142 --> 00:07:42.658
>> Right.

147
00:07:42.658 --> 00:07:45.236
>> So
this is why we have to understand that,

148
00:07:45.236 --> 00:07:49.738
because it's all a part of that same
conversation is what we want to see.

149
00:07:49.738 --> 00:07:52.592
The ability for
those two computers to communicate and

150
00:07:52.592 --> 00:07:55.770
get the message fully across
the way that we want to.

151
00:07:55.770 --> 00:08:00.369
It's not just about sending packets
across, there's more to it.

152
00:08:00.369 --> 00:08:04.907
But Ronnie, it also makes a difference
with different types of transmissions,

153
00:08:04.907 --> 00:08:09.578
right, because if we're talking UDP and
you're giving a story and you're saying

154
00:08:09.578 --> 00:08:14.182
the word IT ProTV, it wouldn't make sense
if you said those letters transposed or

155
00:08:14.182 --> 00:08:18.480
jumbled because we would be like,
what is Ronnie even talking about?

156

00:19:40.673 --> 00:19:44.151
>> So now, we are going to do
the same thing, but this time, so

385
00:19:44.151 --> 00:19:46.660
since it's still running.

386
00:19:46.660 --> 00:19:47.864
This time if I open.

387
00:19:47.864 --> 00:19:49.900
I'm gonna see if I can try and
open up a new terminal.

388
00:19:49.900 --> 00:19:51.110
There we go.

389
00:19:51.110 --> 00:19:52.018
So now I'm outside.

390
00:19:52.018 --> 00:19:54.762
Gonna do a clear here, yup.

391
00:19:54.762 --> 00:19:55.430
>> All right, Ronnie, so

392
00:19:55.430 --> 00:19:58.830
what are we gonna do,
directly SSH into this particular machine?

393
00:19:58.830 --> 00:19:59.440
>> Yes we are.

394
00:19:59.440 --> 00:20:03.890
We're just gonna try and see exactly
what end up happening here when we SSH.

395
00:20:03.890 --> 00:20:05.820
And see what we come up with as results.

396
00:20:05.820 --> 00:20:11.626
So the great thing is, since Wireshark
is still running in the background,

397
00:20:11.626 --> 00:20:16.523
I should just be able to type in SSH and
then admin at this point and

398
00:20:16.523 --> 00:20:20.079
get right back into that
particular machine.

399
00:20:20.079 --> 00:20:22.870
And when I do so,
it's gonna tell me something's wrong here.

400
00:20:22.870 --> 00:20:27.250
Now, we did run into this issue and
we did figure out what was going on here.

401
00:20:27.250 --> 00:20:31.950
And this is actually from one of our
viewers on our live show right now.

402
00:20:31.950 --> 00:20:35.800
He said, hey,
it doesn't support SSH version 1 anymore.

403
00:20:35.800 --> 00:20:38.040
The MacBook that I'm on doesn't do that.

404
00:20:38.040 --> 00:20:40.666
And it's ironic,
because it was just a couple of weeks ago,

405
00:20:40.666 --> 00:20:43.309
we were doing the cybersecurity show,
it worked just fine.

406
00:20:43.309 --> 00:20:46.731
But I did, just two days ago, literally,

407
00:20:46.731 --> 00:20:52.320
updated to the newest OS on MacOS here,
which they call Sierra.

408
00:20:52.320 --> 00:20:55.170
And at least in that one,
it's no longer available.

409
00:20:55.170 --> 00:20:57.607
So there's a couple of
things that I can do.

410
00:20:57.607 --> 00:21:01.990
But here is what I have to type
in to make this work instead.

411
00:21:01.990 --> 00:21:03.870
So we tried it out and
made sure that everything worked so

412
00:21:03.870 --> 00:21:04.980
that we could show you this.

413
00:21:04.980 --> 00:21:11.483
It's still SSH, but now you have to go in
and modify so that it accepts SSH here.

414
00:21:11.483 --> 00:21:15.630
And you'll see that the command is
basically the same at the end, okay.

415
00:21:15.630 --> 00:21:17.140
So this is a modification.

416
00:21:17.140 --> 00:21:20.364
Now, if I wanted to make sure
that this was done all the time,

417
00:21:20.364 --> 00:21:22.410
right, this is where I
have to go back in and

418
00:21:22.410 --> 00:21:26.630
modify a few of the different algorithms
that are actually hosted inside.

419
00:21:26.630 --> 00:21:28.810
But for us, this is all that
we really need to do here.

420
00:21:28.810 --> 00:21:33.011
Now, the great thing is, if this
doesn't work, which I know it will,

421
00:21:33.011 --> 00:21:37.640
I have on hand here, ready to go,
my connection from my Windows machine.

422
00:21:37.640 --> 00:21:39.020
But I wanted to keep it consistent, so

423
00:21:39.020 --> 00:21:42.220
we'll stick right here and
see what happens from this point.

424
00:21:42.220 --> 00:21:46.350
Now, notice it asked me for a password
at this particular point in time.

425
00:21:46.350 --> 00:21:51.500
I type in cisco123 and
now I'm inside of the switch.

426
00:21:51.500 --> 00:21:53.440
Then cisco123 again.

427
00:21:53.440 --> 00:21:56.405
We can do the same commands.

428
00:22:01.513 --> 00:22:04.430
And in a moment it should build
my entire running config.

429
00:22:04.430 --> 00:22:07.749
Remember the first time that we did
this and we showed it in Telnet,

430
00:22:07.749 --> 00:22:10.020
we just saw everything
inside of Wireshark.

431
00:22:10.020 --> 00:22:12.454
And we're able to see
everything here again.

432
00:22:12.454 --> 00:22:17.610
And let me do one more just do make sure,
so we'll do parity check here.

433
00:22:17.610 --> 00:22:21.680
Show, and
I think I did an IP interface brief.

434
00:22:24.050 --> 00:22:28.630
And it's at this point I went ahead and

435
00:22:28.630 --> 00:22:31.220
made an exit,
closed out of that connection.

436
00:22:31.220 --> 00:22:32.041
And now we can try and
see it inside of Wireshark.

437
00:22:32.041 --> 00:22:34.217
And now see, let me go ahead and
do a cancel here.

438
00:22:34.217 --> 00:22:38.142
And, it might not have actually captured
any of that since I had it stopped at

439
00:22:38.142 --> 00:22:38.793
some point.

440
00:22:38.793 --> 00:22:40.750
Let's see,
I'm gonna have to do that again.

441
00:22:40.750 --> 00:22:44.680
So let's see, if I do SSH,
no, there it is,

442
00:22:44.680 --> 00:22:45.340
it did capture-
>> Good, good.

443
00:22:45.340 --> 00:22:45.955
>> I was just trying to make sure,
I was like-

444
00:22:45.955 --> 00:22:46.470
>> [LAUGH].

445
00:22:46.470 --> 00:22:47.550
>> Ooh, did it capture it or not?

446
00:22:47.550 --> 00:22:48.520
But I think it did.

447
00:22:48.520 --> 00:22:51.860
The nice thing, is that even though
I didn't know if it had stopped it,

448
00:22:51.860 --> 00:22:55.920
cuz I hit that mark, we can now see-
>> Yeah, let's check one of these streams.

449
00:22:55.920 --> 00:22:56.939
>> There is the connection.

450
00:22:56.939 --> 00:22:59.360
And now we can check the same thing.

451
00:22:59.360 --> 00:23:03.450
So hold on, let me see if I can
zoom in just a little bit more.

452
00:23:03.450 --> 00:23:04.760
There we go.

453
00:23:04.760 --> 00:23:05.750
So now there it is.

454
00:23:05.750 --> 00:23:07.950
It's all between that and my machine.

455
00:23:09.030 --> 00:23:10.110
I now apply the.

456
00:23:11.490 --> 00:23:14.380
Oops, let me zoom back out so
we can see it, this TCP stream.

457
00:23:15.540 --> 00:23:16.610
And now let's take a look.

458
00:23:18.200 --> 00:23:22.280
Cherokee, I can see some
of the information here.

459
00:23:22.280 --> 00:23:24.150
Remember that there it is.

460
00:23:24.150 --> 00:23:28.585
The blue part is of course
the Cisco server itself or

461
00:23:28.585 --> 00:23:32.120
this switch saying, hey,
here's how I'm connecting.

462
00:23:32.120 --> 00:23:34.460
And this is my MacBook connecting.

463
00:23:34.460 --> 00:23:35.369
So remember, the red is me.

464
00:23:35.369 --> 00:23:39.030
And here is the negotiation that goes on.

465
00:23:39.030 --> 00:23:41.286
Here's what the server
says it will support.

466
00:23:41.286 --> 00:23:47.070
And then here is what mine says it
will now support and allow me to do.

467
00:23:47.070 --> 00:23:51.890
But, Cherokee, I'm not seeing anything
else in the rest of that conversation.

468
00:23:51.890 --> 00:23:57.776
Notice that even the user name that I put
in didn't even show up in any of this.

469
00:23:57.776 --> 00:24:01.170
It shows me the exchange of
the algorithms, or the negotiation.

470
00:24:01.170 --> 00:24:03.394
But I don't actually see anything.

471
00:24:03.394 --> 00:24:09.770
So even with the ability to follow
the stream, that TCP stream.

472
00:24:09.770 --> 00:24:12.820
It really does work, but
sometimes it's not helpful.

473
00:24:12.820 --> 00:24:17.610
So, for example, if I have SSH turned on,
it's not gonna be really helpful for

474
00:24:17.610 --> 00:24:19.120
anything that I'm gonna do.

475
00:24:19.120 --> 00:24:24.230
But at least I know I can go in and
find that if I choose to.

476
00:24:24.230 --> 00:24:25.920
So if I think maybe I'm just mistaken,

477
00:24:25.920 --> 00:24:28.480
I can select another one and
go back to Follow.

478
00:24:28.480 --> 00:24:32.920
And let's see, yep, even right
here on another particular packet.

479
00:24:32.920 --> 00:24:36.120
So I know that I'm not
just randomly picking one,

480
00:24:36.120 --> 00:24:37.610
that's what we're actually seeing here.

481
00:24:37.610 --> 00:24:38.460
>> Can we zoom in a little bit?

482
00:24:38.460 --> 00:24:39.550
>> Sure.
>> I just want to see what that looks

483
00:24:39.550 --> 00:24:41.290
like, a little bit closer to verify.

484
00:24:41.290 --> 00:24:44.135
Yep, there we go,
we can see some information.

485
00:24:44.135 --> 00:24:45.800
>> And it's all about the key exchanges.

486
00:24:45.800 --> 00:24:47.110
That's pretty much what it's saying.

487
00:24:47.110 --> 00:24:49.560
It will support all this
stuff that you see.

488
00:24:49.560 --> 00:24:51.460
So mine is sending them
back anything else.

489
00:24:51.460 --> 00:24:53.435
It's like, all right,
which one do you want to agree to?

490
00:24:53.435 --> 00:24:57.930
Cisco switch, and we'll use that
one is what it will end up saying.

491
00:24:57.930 --> 00:24:59.200
So it is neat.

492
00:24:59.200 --> 00:25:00.385
>> Now you can sleep at night.

493
00:25:00.385 --> 00:25:02.740
>> Yep, at least you hope you can sleep.

494
00:25:02.740 --> 00:25:05.830
Until something else was actually there,
okay?

495
00:25:05.830 --> 00:25:07.010
It's just one of those things.

496
00:25:07.010 --> 00:25:11.520
Yes, you should be a little bit careful
in any type of connection that you make.

497
00:25:11.520 --> 00:25:13.780
But realize,
this way you can verify, right?

498
00:25:13.780 --> 00:25:15.900
If you make a connection and
you're not sure if it's secure or

499
00:25:15.900 --> 00:25:18.990
not, you can at least go back in and
check it here.

500
00:25:18.990 --> 00:25:22.640
And now see, notice that my
running-config didn't show up.

501
00:25:22.640 --> 00:25:24.980
My password or username didn't show up.

502
00:25:24.980 --> 00:25:30.200
All that was exactly what we were
taking a look at here when we were

503
00:25:30.200 --> 00:25:32.130
following that TCP stream.

504
00:25:32.130 --> 00:25:35.250
But there is more that we have to

505
00:25:35.250 --> 00:25:37.870
think about as far as some
of the advanced features.

506
00:25:37.870 --> 00:25:42.280
But following the TCP stream, being able
to see both sides of the conversation

507
00:25:42.280 --> 00:25:45.580
can help you out especially in
troubleshooting, when you go,

508
00:25:45.580 --> 00:25:46.810
I know that I sent this.

509
00:25:46.810 --> 00:25:47.460
And, well,

510
00:25:47.460 --> 00:25:51.440
let's try it again and see if you can
get both sides of the conversation.

511
00:25:51.440 --> 00:25:56.220
Especially if the traffic is unencrypted,
you'll be able to see that.

512
00:25:56.220 --> 00:26:00.870
We just showed you, also, that if you
end up using a secure type of protocol,

513
00:26:00.870 --> 00:26:02.190
then what you should get is what I got.

514
00:26:02.190 --> 00:26:04.710
You see the exchange of the algorithms,
but

515
00:26:04.710 --> 00:26:08.720
notice, none of the other data also
came through where I could inspect it.

516
00:26:08.720 --> 00:26:12.580
So that kind of tells you that it's
pretty much secured at this point, and

517
00:26:12.580 --> 00:26:14.616
that should bring a little
bit of a relief to you.

518
00:26:14.616 --> 00:26:17.290
If somebody is saying,
I don't know if this is secured or not.

519
00:26:17.290 --> 00:26:21.440
Well that's how you can also verify and
check it out for people as well.

520
00:26:21.440 --> 00:26:23.670
>> Well, understanding how
those conversations work,

521
00:26:23.670 --> 00:26:28.030
the banter back and forth and
knowing how to encrypt that information so

522
00:26:28.030 --> 00:26:32.610
one isn't able to eavesdrop,
that is just a great tool to keep in mind.

523
00:26:32.610 --> 00:26:37.045
But I think we do have a time limit here
and it looks like we've reached that.

524
00:26:37.045 --> 00:26:39.346
So thank you so much for joining us today.

525
00:26:39.346 --> 00:26:42.226
And thank you ladies and gentlemen for
tuning in but stay tuned,

526
00:26:42.226 --> 00:26:45.300
we do have some more Wireshark
information headed your way.

527
00:26:45.300 --> 00:26:47.550
But we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this show.

528
00:26:47.550 --> 00:26:49.440
Remember I'm your show
host Cherokee Boose.

529
00:26:49.440 --> 00:26:50.250
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

530
00:26:50.250 --> 00:26:52.625
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

531
00:26:52.625 --> 00:26:59.160
[MUSIC]

532
00:26:59.160 --> 00:27:02.427
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: This is a continuation where Cherokee and Ronnie examine expert information to help narrow the scope of search results. Define these specific searches with parameters such as checksums, sequence info, response codes, request codes, undecoded packets, reassembled packets, malformed packets, protocol types and debug options.
episodes.title: Use Advanced Features Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.187
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.187 --> 00:00:03.432
I'm your host, Don Perez.

3
00:00:03.432 --> 00:00:06.491
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.491 --> 00:00:08.156
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.156 --> 00:00:11.829
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.829 --> 00:00:14.380
>> Welcome to your Wireshark series.

7
00:00:14.380 --> 00:00:16.690
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:20.075
If you've been following along you'll
noticed that we've already taken a look at

9
00:00:20.075 --> 00:00:21.976
some advanced features but
we ran out of time.

10
00:00:21.976 --> 00:00:25.920
So we're gonna pick up right where we left
off, and delve a little bit deeper into

11
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:30.200
some of those advance features, that
we do have available within Wireshark.

12
00:00:30.200 --> 00:00:32.890
With us today we have
Mr Ronnie Wong in studios.

13
00:00:32.890 --> 00:00:34.460
Thank you for joining us today Ronnie.

14
00:00:34.460 --> 00:00:36.780
>> Thank you for having me back,
especially for this part two,

15
00:00:36.780 --> 00:00:40.830
cuz we really didn't get super
far into what we wanted to,

16
00:00:40.830 --> 00:00:42.590
as far as some of the advanced features.

17
00:00:42.590 --> 00:00:44.320
But we did get a pretty good way.

18
00:00:44.320 --> 00:00:46.630
Now, don't get me wrong,
there are tons of them and

19
00:00:46.630 --> 00:00:49.800
we're just trying to show you
a sampling of a couple of them

20
00:00:49.800 --> 00:00:53.490
that will get you interested in
using Wireshark a little bit more.

21
00:00:53.490 --> 00:00:56.580
So, remember that in part one,
right, we showed you, essentially,

22
00:00:56.580 --> 00:00:58.710
how to follow a conversation.

23
00:00:58.710 --> 00:00:59.690
You can do that now.

24
00:00:59.690 --> 00:01:02.300
Remember, TCP stream is not
the only one that's available.

25
00:01:02.300 --> 00:01:04.710
There are other streams that
are available out there, but

26
00:01:04.710 --> 00:01:08.320
it just takes a little bit of time before
you can figure out what they really mean.

27
00:01:08.320 --> 00:01:11.720
But start out with the TCP stream because
that's probably the most useful for

28
00:01:11.720 --> 00:01:12.820
most of us.

29
00:01:12.820 --> 00:01:17.610
But as we continue to move forward into
learning more and more about Wireshark and

30
00:01:17.610 --> 00:01:22.360
its features though, one of the key
things, especially for beginners, okay,

31
00:01:22.360 --> 00:01:25.030
is to take a look at all that
information that's going across.

32
00:01:25.030 --> 00:01:29.967
So, here it is, I'm trying to make sure
on my Wireshark right now it's up to

33
00:01:29.967 --> 00:01:34.456
255,950 packets of the information
that's coming across.

34
00:01:34.456 --> 00:01:37.960
So that's a pretty good amount of packets.

35
00:01:37.960 --> 00:01:40.800
Well, when you first launch it up and
the very first capture that you have and

36
00:01:40.800 --> 00:01:43.590
you leave it running like this,
you might be wondering, like, well,

37
00:01:43.590 --> 00:01:44.970
what am I looking for now, right?

38
00:01:44.970 --> 00:01:47.510
You start to click through and
you start to go,

39
00:01:47.510 --> 00:01:50.320
what of all this stuff am I looking for?

40
00:01:50.320 --> 00:01:52.240
And it doesn't really seem to make sense.

41
00:01:52.240 --> 00:01:55.560
Even if you selected one of them and
now you go, all right, so

42
00:01:55.560 --> 00:02:00.590
now I've selected something, well,
I'm still maybe, if I'm a novice might

43
00:02:00.590 --> 00:02:04.820
not have a good understanding of how this
stuff breaks down yet, or the protocols.

44
00:02:04.820 --> 00:02:08.130
So it can be a little bit
overwhelming if we're not careful.

45
00:02:08.130 --> 00:02:11.110
>> Well, one visual aid that we
might be able to rely on Ronnie,

46
00:02:11.110 --> 00:02:13.800
didn't we talk about different
colors in a previous episode?

47
00:02:13.800 --> 00:02:16.170
>> There's no doubt that
colorizing the packets and

48
00:02:16.170 --> 00:02:20.470
the way that it does it is really helpful
because it does separate out certain

49
00:02:20.470 --> 00:02:22.520
amounts of the way that the data looks.

50
00:02:22.520 --> 00:02:27.800
So if I click on View and
then I select on this Colorize rule

51
00:02:27.800 --> 00:02:32.330
you can now see some of the default
colors that will come across your screen.

52
00:02:32.330 --> 00:02:37.490
So for example, bad TCP and TCP reset and

53
00:02:37.490 --> 00:02:41.380
SCTP abort,
some of this stuff you can see that and

54
00:02:41.380 --> 00:02:46.450
that's the way that you might be able
to do this scan across those packets.

55
00:02:46.450 --> 00:02:48.850
When you see something like right there,

56
00:02:48.850 --> 00:02:51.880
that stands out because it's such
a contrast with everything else.

57
00:02:51.880 --> 00:02:54.160
This black background with the red text,

58
00:02:54.160 --> 00:02:57.130
it really kind of alerts you that
you may wanna pay attention to that.

59
00:02:57.130 --> 00:02:58.780
So I select that.

60
00:02:58.780 --> 00:03:02.230
And then when I select it,
I'm like, okay, great.

61
00:03:02.230 --> 00:03:05.260
What else am I looking for
now that I've selected it?

62
00:03:05.260 --> 00:03:07.880
I don't understand what
else is going on here.

63
00:03:07.880 --> 00:03:11.950
Well, the great thing is that
inside of Wireshark itself,

64
00:03:11.950 --> 00:03:15.290
you do have the advantage to be
able to find more information.

65
00:03:15.290 --> 00:03:17.290
Now, if you wanna do it manually,
this is what you do.

66
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:19.736
So, Cherokee,
all you have to do is look for

67
00:03:19.736 --> 00:03:24.185
every single packet that's out there that
has a black background and red text.

68
00:03:24.185 --> 00:03:25.072
>> Good luck with that.

69
00:03:25.072 --> 00:03:26.913
You had, what, 225,000?

70
00:03:26.913 --> 00:03:28.397
>> 256,000 packets now.

71
00:03:28.397 --> 00:03:29.256
>> 56 now.
[LAUGH]

72
00:03:29.256 --> 00:03:30.923
>> Yeah, it's starting to head

73
00:03:30.923 --> 00:03:32.390
north a little bit.

74
00:03:32.390 --> 00:03:34.890
So let's say that there
are several thousand of these.

75
00:03:34.890 --> 00:03:36.550
Even if I find all of them,

76
00:03:36.550 --> 00:03:41.450
right, it still may not allow me
to make much sense of it, okay?

77
00:03:41.450 --> 00:03:46.358
But there are some tools that really help
us to focus in on the very fact that

78
00:03:46.358 --> 00:03:49.922

302
00:16:16.080 --> 00:16:20.200
and you'll be able to come back to this
and use this at any time in your career.

303
00:16:20.200 --> 00:16:22.820
As a novice, to just help you get started.

304
00:16:22.820 --> 00:16:26.790
If you're an expert, okay, what this
will do is even if you can identify

305
00:16:26.790 --> 00:16:30.240
every packet, it gives you the ability
to become more efficient, all right,

306
00:16:30.240 --> 00:16:33.530
because Wireshark is racing,
let me group them together for you and

307
00:16:33.530 --> 00:16:35.405
that way you can see
them a little bit easier.

308
00:16:35.405 --> 00:16:39.655
So take advantage of using
the expert tools here and the skills

309
00:16:39.655 --> 00:16:43.727
that will now help you to investigate
a little bit further along the line.

310
00:16:43.727 --> 00:16:45.772
>> All right, well, thank you so
much for joining us to day, Ronnie.

311
00:16:45.772 --> 00:16:49.917
And thank you ladies and gentlemen for
looking at what we have in our advanced

312
00:16:49.917 --> 00:16:53.047
features and
really investigating those expert tools.

313
00:16:53.047 --> 00:16:56.982
Hopefully they'll help you all out in
the future but that does wrap it up for

314
00:16:56.982 --> 00:16:58.430
this particular episode.

315
00:16:58.430 --> 00:17:00.510
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this show.

316
00:17:00.510 --> 00:17:02.440
Remember, I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

317
00:17:02.440 --> 00:17:03.350
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

318
00:17:03.350 --> 00:17:06.291
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

319
00:17:06.291 --> 00:17:12.257
[MUSIC]

320
00:17:12.257 --> 00:17:18.369
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: Ronnie and Cherokee look at ways to help understand output. Ronnie explains and demonstrates how General statistics provide granular information in text or graphical representation.
